266.01-1  DURATION OF PERSONNEL POLICY.
   This Personnel Policy shall be effective unless and until modified by the
City.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.01-2  COVERAGE.
   This Personnel Policy covers the wages, hours of work and all other terms
and conditions of employment of all individuals employed by the City of
Perrysburg, Ohio who are not in bargaining units covered by collective
bargaining agreements.  It does not however cover casual employees (e.g.
volunteer fire employees), temporary or seasonal employees (e.g. summer
employees) or part-time employees, who normally work fewer than thirty (30)
hours per week, or employees of the Court.  Any provisions covering pay,
benefits and terms and conditions of employment for non-bargaining employees
who are excluded from the Personnel Policy must be specified as such in City
Ordinances other than in this Personnel Policy. 
(Ord. 182-2009.  Passed 10-6-09.)
266.01-3  NOMENCLATURE.
   The City Administrator, Director of Public Service, Director of Law,
Director of Finance, Director of Public Safety, and the Director of Public
Utilities will be called the Executive Staff.  The Division Heads, Prosecutor,
Clerk of the Municipal Court, and Deputy Director of Public Service will be
called the Senior Administrative Staff.  The Deputy Department and Division
Heads, Police Lieutenants, Engineering Technician, Human Resources Manager,
Assistant Superintendents, Operation Supervisors, Information Technology
Manager, Software Specialist, Wastewater Treatment Plant Manager, and the
Support Services Manager will be called the Administrative Staff.  The
remaining individuals covered by the Personnel Policy will be called the
Special Support Staff.  When referred collectively, individuals covered by the
Personnel Policy may be referred to as staff members.  Less than full-time
staff members means those working thirty or more hours per week, but less than
full-time.
(Ord. 2-2014.  Passed 1-7-14.)
266.02-1  CITY AUTHORITY.
   The City shall have all rights, powers and authority customarily exercised
by management except as expressly modified by specific language of this
Personnel Policy.  Such rights, powers and authority shall include, but not be
limited to, the determination and implementation of functions and programs; the
standards of services; the utilization of technology; the organizational
structure; the direction of, supervision, evaluation or hiring of staff
members; the maintenance and improvement of efficiency and effectiveness of the
City's operations; the determination of the overall methods, processes, means
or personnel by which the City's operations are to be conducted including the
contracting out of work; the suspension, discipline, demotion, discharge of
staff members for just cause, the layoff, transfer, assignment, scheduling,
promotion or retention of staff members; the determination of the adequacy of
the workforce; the determination of the overall mission of the City as a unit
of government; the effective management of the workforce; the taking of actions
to carry out the mission of the City as a governmental unit; and the making,
modification and application of rules and regulations for safety, efficiency
and discipline.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.02-2  RULES GOVERNING SAFETY, HEALTH AND CONDUCT.
   The City may implement, alter and/or amend rules governing the safety,
health and conduct of staff members, a violation of which shall be among the
causes for discharge or other disciplinary action.  The City will post any new
rule for a period of fourteen (14) calendar days prior to its implementation. 
All staff members covered by this Personnel Policy shall be given a current set
of rules no later than thirty (30) days after the date a rule is implemented.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.02-3  TOBACCO USE PROHIBITED.
   Tobacco use and use of e-cigarettes inside City owned buildings, vehicles,
equipment or in any other City facility is prohibited.  Police officers will
not be permitted to use any tobacco projects or e-cigarettes while in uniform. 
Any employee covered by this policy who violates this rules will be subject to
discipline under the provisions of Section
266.03-4 of this policy.
(Ord. 119-2015.  Passed 12-15-15.)
266.03-1  DISPUTE SETTLEMENT STEPS.
   It is the desire of the City to provide for the prompt adjustment of
disputes in a fair and reasonable manner, with a minimum amount of interruption
of work schedules.  Every reasonable effort shall be made by the City and the
aggrieved staff members to effect resolution of disputes at the earliest step
possible.
   A dispute shall mean any difference which arises between the City and any
staff member below the Executive or Senior Administrative Staff Level covered
by this Personnel Policy regarding the meaning or application of the provisions
of this Personnel Policy or work rules.  The dispute settlement procedure under
this Personnel Policy shall take the place of any appeal to the State Personnel
Board of Review.  Disputes shall be processed in the following manner:
(Ord. 78-97.  Passed 6-3-97.)
   STEP 1: The staff member shall first present the dispute orally with that
staff member’s Division Head or his/her designee.  If a satisfactory settlement
is not achieved within five working days, the staff member shall reduce the
dispute to writing and present it to the Human Resources Manager within five
additional working days.
   STEP 2: Within ten working days of when the dispute is reduced to writing
and referred to Step 2, the staff member with a dispute shall meet with the
Human Resources Manager or his/her designee and the Division Head.  The City
will provide the staff member with its answer in writing within five working
days of the date of the Step 2 meeting.
   STEP 3:  If appealed to Step 3 by the staff member within five working days
of when the City gives its Step 2 answer, within an additional ten working days
the staff member with a dispute and a personal representative of the staff
member, who shall be a staff member of the City, shall meet with the Mayor or
the Mayor’s designee, the City Administrator, the Human Resources Manager, and
such other City officials as the Mayor or the Mayor’s designee deems
appropriate.  The City will provide the staff member with its final answer in
writing within five working days of the date of the Step 3 meeting.  The City’s
final answer shall be final and binding upon the staff member with a dispute
and all other affected staff members unless appealed to Step 4 by the staff
member with a dispute in writing and received by the City within five working
days of the City’s Step 3 answer.  (Ord. 110-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
   STEP 4:  If no satisfactory settlement is achieved between the City and the
staff member with a dispute at Step 3 and timely appeal is made by the staff
member with a dispute, the dispute may be submitted to arbitration.  Within ten
(10) working days after the City receives the timely appeal to Step 4,
representatives of the City and the staff member with a dispute or his/her
personal representative shall attempt to select a neutral arbitrator to hear
and determine the matter being referred to arbitration. If the representatives
of the City and the staff member with a dispute or his/her personal
representative are unable to agree upon a neutral arbitrator within the ten
(10) working day period mentioned above, the City and the staff member with a
dispute shall jointly petition the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service
no later than ten (10) working days after the City receives the timely appeal
to Step 4.  The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service shall submit a panel
of seven (7) arbitrators from which panel an arbitrator shall be selected by
striking names or by mutual agreement of the City and the staff member with a
dispute.  Subsequent panels of arbitrators may be requested where either the
City or the staff member with a dispute determines none of the arbitrators on
the panel is acceptable.  The City or the staff member with a dispute, or both,
shall notify the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service of the name of the
arbitrator selected. 
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.03-2  POWERS OF ARBITRATOR AND COSTS OF ARBITRATION.
   The arbitrator shall only have jurisdiction and authority to interpret,
apply and determine compliance with the provisions of this Personnel Policy,
but shall not have jurisdiction or authority to add to, detract from or alter
the terms of this Personnel Policy in any manner nor shall the Arbitrator have
the jurisdiction or authority to assess a penalty or to determine any matter
which might be construed as an interest arbitration.  Inadvertent errors in
application of the provisions of this Personnel Policy by the City shall not be
construed to be an enforceable practice.  The decision of the arbitrator shall
adequately set forth the issue or issues to be decided, the positions of the
parties, specific findings of fact, conclusions of law, and the award.  The
arbitrator's decision and award shall be binding upon the City, the staff
member with a dispute and all other affected staff members unless set aside or
modified by a court of competent jurisdiction.  The arbitrator shall render
his/her award within thirty (30) days of the date of the hearing or within
thirty (30) days of the date briefs are filed, whichever is later.  Each party
shall bear the cost of its own presentation.  The cost of any transcript and
attendance free shall be borne by the party arranging for the court reporter. 
The expense of the arbitrator shall be borne by the City if the City loses the
arbitration or equally by the City and the staff member with a dispute if the
staff member with a dispute loses the arbitration.
   Any agreement reached between the City and the staff member with a dispute
in resolution of a dispute prior to arbitration shall be final and binding upon
the City, the staff member with a dispute and all other affected staff members;
provided, however, that nothing herein shall prohibit the staff member with a
dispute and the City from agreeing that a particular resolution of a dispute
shall not be used as a precedent in any future cases of any kind.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.03-3  TIME LIMITS FOR FILING DISPUTES.
   Disputes concerning discharge of a staff member shall be submitted in
writing at Step 4 of the Dispute Settlement Procedure within three (3) working
days of the date of the discharge or the date the City issues its final
decision following a discharge hearing, whichever is later.  Copies of the
dispute will be provided to the City.  Any other dispute shall be submitted at
Step 1 of the Dispute Settlement Procedure within five (5) working days of the
date the alleged violation occurred.  For purposes of the Dispute Settlement
Procedure, working days shall mean Monday through Friday, excluding holidays
celebrated during that period.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.03-4  DISCIPLINE AND SEPARATION FROM EMPLOYMENT.
   A.   GENERALLY:
      Violation of City rules governing the safety, health and/or conduct of
staff members covered by this Personnel Policy shall be among the causes for
separation from employment or other disciplinary action.  Separation from
employment or other disciplinary action may be subject to the Dispute
Settlement Procedure under this Personnel Policy for staff members below the
level of Executive or Senior Administrative Staff provided the staff member has
completed his/her probation period.
   B.   MAJOR VIOLATION:
      A violation of major City rules governing safety, conduct and/or health
of staff members may be among the causes for involuntary separation from
employment.  Major violations by way of example and not by way of limitation,
may be falsification of any documents required by the City; unauthorized
disclosure of sensitive or confidential information such as tax returns; being
under the influence of and/or the unauthorized possession, sale or purchase of
alcohol or illicit drugs during working hours; physical violence; engaging in
gross insubordination; conviction of a felony; embezzlement of public funds;
theft, pilferage or unauthorized possession of property; engaging in conduct or
encouraging others to engage in conduct in violation of this Personnel Policy,
including but not limited to, the no strike provision; or any offense involving
gross misconduct.
   C.   LESSER VIOLATIONS:
      With respect to non-probationary staff members below the level of
Executive or Senior Administrative Staff level, for violations of lesser City
rules governing safety, conduct and/or health of staff members, progressive
discipline will be used, consistent with the seriousness of the offense and the
work record of the staff member.
   D.   NOTICE OF DISCIPLINARY ACTION:
      Every counselling memo, suspension notice or separation from employment
notice shall be in writing and shall contain at a minimum the date given, the
name of the individual issuing it, the name of the staff member receiving the
warning, the nature of the alleged violation and the date or dates upon which
the alleged violation occurred.  A non-probationary staff member shall receive
a copy within five (5) days of the City's gaining knowledge of the infraction
unless the nature of the infraction requires additional investigation time to
be determined by the City.  The investigation time shall be reasonable.  A copy
shall be retained by the City in the staff member's personnel file.  Executive
or Senior Administrative Staff Members will have a verbal discussion with
Management in cases of discipline short of suspension of employment, although
the file documentation will be similar to the formal method described above.
   E.   CLEARING OF STAFF MEMBER'S RECORD:
      Disciplinary action will expire from a non-probationary staff member's
work record in accordance with the following schedule:
      1.   ORAL COUNSELLING MEMO - one (1) year from the date of the reprimand.
      2.   WRITTEN COUNSELLING MEMO - two (2) years from the date of the
reprimand.
      3.   SUSPENSION COUNSELLING MEMO OF THREE (3) DAYS OR LESS - three (3)
years from the date of the suspension.
      4.   SUSPENSION COUNSELLING MEMO OF FOUR (4) DAYS OR MORE - four (4)
years from the date of the suspension.
   F.   HEARING:
      No staff member will be involuntarily separated from employment or
suspended for more than three (3) days from employment with the City without
first being given the opportunity for a hearing before the Mayor or the Mayor's
designee.  The burden shall be on the City in all involuntary separation cases,
except those where the staff member is considered separated for overstaying a
leave of absence or for being absent for three (3) consecutive work days
without reporting such absence to the City or for failure to report or work
within five (5) working days after receipt of a certified letter notifying the
staff member of a recall to work following a layoff.
   The City and the staff member shall have the right to support of their
respective positions.  All public records pertinent to the proceedings shall be
made available unless disclosure is prohibited by law.  The City shall issue
its final determination to the affected staff member within seven (7) calendar
days following the close of the hearing.  If the employment separation or
suspension is sustained as a result of the hearing, the staff member shall have
three (3) work days following the date of the City's final determination in
which to file a dispute at Step 4 of the dispute settlement procedure.
   G.   VOLUNTARY SEPARATION IN LIEU OF INVOLUNTARY SEPARATION:
      A staff member may resign at any time prior to a final employment
separation decision and his/her personnel file shall show a voluntary
separation from employment.  If a staff member resigns in accordance with this
provision, the staff member shall not thereafter file for unemployment
compensation in a manner which will cause the City liability; and if the staff
member does so, the City will have the right to contend before the OBES that
the staff member was involuntarily separated from employment.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.03-5  PERSONNEL FILES.
   A  staff member may be permitted to review the staff member’s own personnel
file and copy any material found therein at any reasonable time and place
(excluding weekends and holidays).  Should the staff member, upon review of
his/her personnel file come across material of negative or derogatory nature,
the staff member may provide a written and signed comment in rebuttal,
mitigation or explanation of such material, which comment shall remain in the
staff member’s file so long as the negative material remains.  Reviews will be
on the staff member’s own time.  Any material copied from the file will be at
the expense of the staff member.
(Ord. 157-2006.  Passed 8-1-06.)
266.03-6  RIGHTS OF STAFF MEMBERS.
   Staff Members of the Police and Fire Divisions below the Senior
Administrative Staff level and subject to this Personnel Policy shall be
entitled to the following rights as they relate to non-criminal charges against
a staff member for violation of Division policies, rules, and regulations.  A
staff member being investigated for possible criminal charges shall be afforded
the same constitutional rights as are required to be provided to any other
citizen.
   A.   In any disciplinary hearing arising out of an investigation under
266.06-3, the City and the staff member shall have the right to question the
other party's witnesses.  Complaints against a staff member for violation of
division policy and procedure shall be reduced to writing and signed by the
Complainant.
   B.   A staff member who is to be questioned as a suspect in any
investigation of any criminal charge against the staff member shall be advised
of their constitutional rights before any questioning starts.  Any internal
division questioning of the staff member named in the criminal complaint and
any administrative charge against that staff member may be delayed until after
the trial stage of the criminal case at the discretion of the Division Head and
shall be delayed until after the trial stage of the criminal case provided: 
(1)  the staff member involved declines to participate in the administrative
investigation and (2)  the staff member removes himself/herself from duty
without pay. (Ord. 78-97.  Passed 6-3-97.)
   C.   Before a staff member may be charged with any violation of Division
rules and regulations for a refusal to answer questions or participate in an
investigation, the staff member shall be advised that his/her refusal to answer
questions or participate in such investigation may be made a basis for such a
charge.
   D.   Any interrogation, questioning or interview shall be conducted at a
reasonable hour, preferably while the staff member to be interrogated or
interviewed is working.  Such sessions shall be for reasonable periods of time
and time shall be allowed for rest periods and other physical necessities.  No
more than two interrogators at a time will interrogate, question or interview
the staff member.
   E.   The staff member shall be informed of the nature of the investigation
prior to any questioning. 
(Ord. 110-94.  Passed 9-20-94.)
   F.   When an anonymous complaint is made against a staff member, the staff
member shall be apprised of the circumstance.  When a single anonymous
complaint is made against a staff member and there is no corroborative evidence
of any kind the staff member accused shall not be required to submit to
interrogation or make a report.  In the event there is corroborative evidence,
the staff member shall be required to submit to interrogation and/or make a
report or statement.  A confidential complaint shall not be considered as an
anonymous complaint, except in those instances in which the person making the
complaint is unwilling to testify in any subsequent hearing.  Where no
compliant has been received and there is no reason to suspect a violation, City
administrators, command officers, and/or supervisors shall not initiate
solicitation of complaints. 
(Ord. 78-97.  Passed 6-3-97.)
   G.   The City may divulge the fact that a particular staff member is under
investigation, but there shall be no release of any additional information by
the City or the staff member regarding the staff member under investigation
until such investigation is completed and the staff member is either cleared or
charged.
   H.   When a staff member suspected of a violation of Division Policies,
rules or regulations is being interrogated, such interrogation shall be
recorded at the request of the staff member or the City.  The party requesting
the recording shall be responsible for the cost unless both parties desire a
copy, wherein the cost shall be equally shared.  In addition, the party
requesting the recording shall be responsible for providing the appropriate
recording equipment.
   I.   A staff member who has been charged with a violation of any Division
Policy, rule or regulation, shall, upon request, be provided the opportunity to
inspect and obtain copies, at current reproduction cost, of transcripts,
recordings, written statements and any other material relating to the charges
as a condition of its use at a hearing on such charge.  Such requests must be
made not less than twenty-four hours prior to the scheduled hearing; however,
the parties may waive the twenty-four hour provision in the event of
extenuating circumstances.
   J.   Any evidence obtained in the course of an internal investigation
through the use of administrative pressures, threats or promises made to the
staff member shall not be used by the City in any subsequent court action.
   K.   In the course of an internal investigation, a polygraph examination
will be administered consistent with applicable law.  When such a polygraph
examination is conducted, upon the consent of the staff member under
investigation, the result of such examination shall not be used by either party
for any purpose in a subsequent court action.
   L.   When a staff member is to be interviewed in an investigation of any
other staff member of the City employee, such interview shall be conducted in
accordance with the procedure established herein.
   M.   If the rights of the staff member who is under investigation as
provided herein have been violated, the violation shall be subject to the
dispute settlement procedure specified in
266.03-1, but commencing at the third step of such procedure.
(Ord. 110-94.  Passed 9-20-94.)
   N.   Internal investigations with regard to minor violations shall be
completed within forty-five calendar days after the filing of the complaint.
   Major complaint investigations, other than criminal complaints involving
felony violations, shall be completed within one hundred calendar days after
filing of the original complaint unless, upon request of the Safety Director,
an extension of time for such investigation to be completed is granted.  The
staff member must be notified of the Safety Director’s decision upon the
granting of the extension request.
   An additional fifteen calendar days shall be provided beyond the forty-five
or one hundred day limits above in cases where the investigation is not
initiated by internal investigation.
   Criminal complaints involving felony investigations shall be investigated
and completed in accordance with the statute of limitations set out in the Ohio
Revised Code.  Such complaints may be referred for investigation by Bureau of
Criminal Identification and Investigation.
(Ord. 110-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
266.04-1  LENGTH OF SERVICE.
   Length of Service or City-wide length of service shall be measured from the
staff member's most recent date of hire with the City.
   Classification length of service shall be measured from the staff member's
most recent date of employment in employee's regularly assigned classification.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.04-2  PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   All non-fire and non-police division staff members below the Executive or
Senior Administrative Staff level covered by this Personnel Policy shall be
considered probationary staff members during the first six months of their most
recent employment with the City.  The probationary period may be extended an
additional ninety calendar days by the City upon written notice to the staff
member before the end of the initial probationary period.  Extension of the
probationary period shall be subject to the dispute settlement procedure.  Fire
Division and Police Division staff members and staff members of the Executive
or Senior Administrative Staff Level, and the Human Resources Manager shall be
considered probationary staff members for the first year of their most recent
employment with the City with an evaluation being given at or near the end of
the first six months.  During probation, staff members covered by the Personnel
Policy may be separated from employment or disciplined without recourse to the
dispute settlement procedure for any reason and will receive no benefits other
than health insurance benefits except as may be statutorily required.  Upon
successful completion of the probationary period a staff member will receive
length of service credit retroactive to the staff members’ most recent date of
hire.
(Ord.  13-01.  Passed 1-16-01.)
266.04-3  LOSS OF LENGTH OF SERVICE CREDIT.
   Length of Service shall be considered broken and the staff member shall be
considered separated from employment when the staff member is involuntarily
separated from employment, voluntarily separated from employment, overstays an
approved leave of absence or any extension thereof, engages in gainful
employment while on an approved leave of absence without the knowledge and
written approval of the City, is absent for three (3) consecutive work days
without reporting such absence to the City, is laid off for a period of time
equal to the staff member's length of service at the time of the layoff not to
exceed a period of eighteen (18) consecutive months, or fails to report for
work within five (5) working days after receipt of a certified letter notifying
the staff member of a recall to work following a layoff.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.04-4  VACANCIES.
   When the City determines there is a vacancy in a new or existing
classification, the City may temporarily assign a staff member to work in that
classification pending the filling of the vacancy.  The City may post a vacancy
for a period of five (5) calendar days during which period staff members in
lower rated classifications may sign the posting.  The City may choose to have
the Civil Service Commission provide the City with an eligibility list of three
individuals from among those who signed the posting and/or who are external
candidates or the City may fill the vacancy.
   A current City staff member chosen to fill the vacancy will have a trial
period up to a maximum of thirty (30) calendar days.  During the trial period a
current staff member may be disqualified or may disqualify himself/herself.  A
staff member who is disqualified or who self-disqualifies during the trial
period shall return to his/her former classification, if still vacant or be
laid off until a vacancy occurs.  A staff member hired to fill a vacancy shall
be governed by the Probationary Period provisions under
266.04-2 of this Personnel Policy.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
   Effective December 17, 1991, when any individual is promoted to any staff
position, other than a Senior Administrative staff position, such individual
will be placed at the step level that will give such individual a rate higher
than the rate for the step two steps higher than the individual's current step
in the classification from which the individual is promoted.
   Effective May 1, 2000, when any individual is promoted to a Senior
Administrative Staff Position or a person is newly hired to such position, that
person will be placed at the appropriate step as determined by the City.
   A newly hired staff member will be placed at the appropriate step as
determined by the City.  (Ord. 37-92.  Passed 4-7-92; Ord. 87-2000.  Passed 6-
20-00.)
266.05-1  WORKING HOURS.
   Working hours shall be determined by the Senior Administrative Staff Member
with the approval of the City Administrator.  (Ord. 110-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
266.05-2  OVERTIME PAY FOR NON-EXEMPT STAFF MEMBERS.
   (a)   For staff members (outside the Police and Fire Divisions) below the
Executive and Senior Administrative Staff level, all work actually performed in
excess of eight (8) hours in a day or forty (40) in a week will be paid at one
and one-half (1-1/2) times a staff member's normal rate of pay.  Unless
specified, unworked time shall not be considered as hours worked for purposes
of this Personnel Policy, except that paid time off work on holidays, vacation
and compensatory time shall be counted as hours worked for the purpose of
computing overtime.  Work actually performed on Saturdays or Sundays which are
outside the employee's normal work week, or on holidays which are not normally
scheduled workdays shall be paid at one and one-half (1-1/2) times a staff
member's hourly rate of pay.  Holiday pay will be paid in accordance with
266.07-2 and
266.07-3 in addition to pay for hours worked on a holiday.  Staff members below
the Executive and Senior Administrative Staff level in the Police Division and
Fire Division shall receive overtime pay based upon the following methods of
calculation:
(Ord. 117-95.  Passed 8-22-95.)
   For Police and Fire Division members  on eight hour shifts, all work
performed in excess of eight hours in a day or forty hours in a ten day period,
will be paid at one and one-half times the staff members normal rate of pay. 
For purposes of this provision, a day shall be measured as a twenty-four hour
consecutive hour period, commencing at the start of the day shift.  (Ord. 158-
2006.  Passed 8-15-06.)
   (b)   Overtime work for all staff members must be authorized in advance by
the Administrator or the Mayor or immediate supervisor, except in case of
emergencies.
(Ord. 159-2006.  Passed 8-1-06.)
266.05-3  COMPENSATORY TIME FOR NON-EXEMPT STAFF MEMBERS.
   Non-exempt staff members may elect to use up to 160 hours of compensatory
time in lieu of pay for overtime hours worked in a calendar year.  The election
shall be in writing and must be made immediately following the end of the work
week in which the overtime is worked.  Each overtime hour worked shall be equal
to one and one-half (1 ½) hours of compensatory time.  No staff member may
accumulate more than eighty (80) hours of compensatory time and when a staff
member is at the maximum accumulation limit for compensatory time; all overtime
worked shall be paid.  So long as it will not unduly disrupt the operations of
the City, a staff member will be permitted to take compensatory time off within
a reasonable time after requesting it.  Compensatory time off may be used in
increments of not less than one (1) hour.  Pay for accrued compensatory time
shall be at the regular rate of the staff member at the time payment is made,
except for cases of termination of employment where pay shall be at the average
regular rate of the staff member during the last three (3) years of employment
or the regular rate of the staff member at the time the payment is made,
whichever is higher.  Employees shall be permitted to cash in up to forty (40)
hours of accumulated compensatory time two (2) times in a calendar year. 
Requests shall be submitted at least two (2) pay periods in advance and shall
be paid in the payroll check.  (Ord. 180-2009.  Passed 10-6-09.)
266.05-4  TRADING TIME.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former Section
266.05-4 was repealed by Ordinance 161-2006.)
266.06-1  SICKNESS, ACCIDENT, DISABILITY AND PREGNANCY LEAVES.
   Leaves under this section for purposes authorized by the Family and Medical
Leave Act shall be charged against eligibility for leaves under Section
266.06-7, Family and Medical Leaves of Absence, until the same has been
exhausted.
   Leaves of absence for sickness, accident or disability (including pregnancy)
shall be granted in writing when the City is presented with a physician’s
certificate indicating the reason the staff member is unable to work and the
anticipated duration of the leave.  Such leaves of absence shall be for a
minimum of seven calendar days and a maximum of thirty calendar day periods up
to a maximum of one hundred eighty (180) days within a twenty-four month period
or three hundred sixty-five (365) days within a twenty-four month period for a
Workers’ Compensation Disability.  Any request for extension must be
accompanied by a physician’s certificate setting forth the same type of
information as is required by the original leave of absence.
   The City may require a more detailed explanation of a staff member’s
disability or at any time(s) during a leave of absence or any extension thereof
or at the end of a leave of absence, the City may require the staff member to
be examined by the City’s physician to determine whether or not the staff
member is able to work.  If the City’s physician and the staff member’s
physician are unable to agree on whether the staff member is able to work the
City shall choose a third physician who shall forthwith examine the staff
member and whose written decision shall be final and binding upon the City and
the staff member.  The examination by the City physician and third physician
shall be at City expense.  If it is determined by the staff member’s physician
or by the third physician that the staff member is able to work, the staff
member shall report for work for the following day after being notified by the
City to do so.  Failure of the staff member to report for work shall be
considered as overstaying an approved leave of absence.  A staff member on a
leave of absence under this part must exhaust accrued, but unused sick leave
and may then use accrued but unused vacation pay.  When sick leave and vacation
pay are exhausted, the staff member will be on an unpaid leave.  Staff members
eligible for accident compensation benefits under
266.09-3 will not be eligible to use accrued but unused sick leave or vacation
pay.  The City will continue to pay health insurance premiums on behalf of the
employee for the first sixty days of an unpaid leave under this section and/or
Section
266.06-7 is exhausted, whichever is later and thereafter the employee must pay
the full premium rate to the City to maintain health insurance in effect. 
(Ord.  37-2004.  Passed 4-20-04.)
266.06-2  JURY DUTY AND WITNESS LEAVES.
   A staff member called for Jury Duty must notify his/her supervisor the next
workday following such notification.  The City will pay the staff member full
pay while the staff member is on jury duty provided the staff member endorses
any jury duty pay he/she receives over to the City.  The provisions with
respect to jury duty shall apply to a staff member subpoenaed as a witness in
any matter arising out of his/her official capacity with the City.  It is the
intent of
266.06-2 that the City pay the difference between an eligible staff member's
straight time wage rate and what the staff member received as a juror or
witness for work time lost due to jury duty or witness duty during the staff
member's regular work day.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.06-3  BEREAVEMENT LEAVE.
   In case of death of a staff member's child, current spouse, mother, father,
brother or sister, grandmother, grandfather or any other relative residing in
the household of the staff member, the Mayor or the Mayor's designee may upon
request grant a leave of absence from the day of death until and including the
day after the funeral not to exceed three (3) working days.  Full-time staff
members will receive eight (8) hours pay or twenty-four (24) hours pay at the
applicable straight rate for each day of funeral leave.  Less than full-time
staff members will receive the leave time off with seventy-five (75%) percent
of full pay.
   In case of death of a mother-in-law, father-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-
law, stepmother, stepfather or grandchild, the staff member will be granted a
leave of absence from the date of death until and including the day after the
funeral not to exceed two (2) working days.  Full-time staff members will
receive eight (8) hours of pay or twenty-four (24) hours pay as applicable at
the applicable straight time rate for each day of funeral leave, provided that
the second day of such leave shall be charged as paid sick leave.  In case of
death of an aunt or uncle the staff member will be granted a one day leave of
absence as described above in this paragraph, and full-time staff members will
receive eight (8) hours of pay or twenty-four hours pay as applicable at the
applicable straight time rate.  Less than full-time staff members will receive
the leave time off with seventy-five (75%) percent of full pay.
   If a holiday occurs while a staff member is on funeral leave, the staff
member will be paid for the funeral leave or the holiday, but not for both.
   In case the funeral or burial is one hundred fifty (150) miles or more from
the City of Perrysburg, a full-time staff member will be entitled to one (1)
additional workday of paid sick leave, if the staff member is scheduled to work
that day.  Less than full-time staff will receive the leave time off with
prorated pay.  (Ord. 78-97.  Passed 6-3-97.)
266.06-4  MILITARY LEAVE.
   A.   A staff member shall be on leave of absence while in military service
for such period of time as the law requires.  Upon discharge the staff member
shall have ninety calendar days to report back to the City to be reassigned in
accordance with the law.  The staff member shall accrue “Length of Service”
credit during a military leave as if the staff member had continued to work for
the City during such military leave.  A staff member on this or any other
unpaid leave of absence shall neither accrue nor be entitled to any other
contractual benefits.  Vacancies created by Military Leave may temporarily be
filled by the City.
   Effective September 18, 1997, a staff member required to go on temporary
active status with the federal or state military service shall be entitled to a
leave of absence without loss of pay for scheduled regular work hours during
such service, not to exceed twenty-two eight-hour days or one hundred seventy-
six work hours within one calendar year.  To qualify for temporary active
status compensation the appropriate orders from the federal or state military
service must be presented to the Mayor or the Mayor’s designee.  Contractual
benefits will continue while a staff member is on annual temporary active
status.
      (1)   While on temporary active status the City will continue to provide
the same health insurance benefits that the staff member was provided under
this personnel policy.
      (2)   While on temporary active status beyond the time period specified
earlier in this section, the City will pay the staff member the difference
between gross military pay and their gross straight time City pay.  A staff
member must first exhaust accrued, but unused vacation and compensatory time
before the pay differential provision will apply.
      
   B.   Employees who are members of the National Disaster Medical Systems
(NDMS) Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) shall be entitled to a
military leave of absence from their duties without loss of pay for such time
as they are in service on field training or active duty.  (Ord. 120-2015. 
Passed 12-15-15.)
266.06-5  PERSONAL LEAVE OF ABSENCE.
   The Mayor or the Mayor’s designee may grant a staff member a leave of
absence without pay for such purposes, periods of time and under such
conditions that the Mayor or the Mayor’s designee may specify.  A staff member
must submit written application to the Mayor or the Mayor’s designee.  Such
leaves will be considered with due regard to the needs of the staff member.
   Leaves granted under this section for purposes authorized by the Family and
Medical Leave Act shall be charged against eligibility for leaves thereunder
until the same has been exhausted consistent with Section
266.06-7.
(Ord. 38-2004.  Passed 4-20-04.)
266.06-6  FATAL FORCE LEAVE.
   When a Police Division staff member has to administer such force as to fall
into the category of Fatal Force, the staff member may request, or the Chief of
Police may require, the staff member to have necessary time off or a
reassignment to an office detail if available, to relieve the stress resulting
from the use of Fatal Force.  Necessary time off or reassignment shall not
initially exceed seven (7) calendar days per incident, unless extended by the
Chief where additional leave is necessary.  To qualify for Fatal Force leave,
the staff member must be evaluated by a qualified practitioner, chosen by the
City, and determined to be in need of such leave; and if a course of treatment
is required, the staff member must agree to undergo same with a practitioner
chosen by the City.  The City will pay the difference in cost between what the
health insurance covers and the staff member's liability for up to five (5) one
hour counselling sessions.  A staff member off work on a Fatal Force leave will
receive his/her regular wages for work missed during the staff member's regular
work day.  Such leave shall not be charged against the staff member's sick
leave credit.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.06-7  FAMILY AND MEDICAL LEAVES.
   An employee who has been employed by the City for one year or more and who
has worked at least 1250 hours within the previous twelve month period will be
granted a leave of up to twelve weeks in any rolling twelve month period for
birth or adoption of a child or to care for a child, spouse or parent with a
serious medical condition.  Any employee who has a serious medical condition
which prevents the employee from working will be granted the leave without
qualifying year or minimum hour requirements.
   To be eligible for a leave to care for a child, spouse or parent with a
serious health condition, an employee must provide, at the time the leave is
requested, a certificate from a doctor or other health care provider setting
forth the beginning date of the serious health condition for which the leave is
sought, the probable duration of the condition, appropriate medical facts
concerning the condition, a statement of why the employee is needed to care for
the child, spouse or parent with an estimate of the time required.  To be
eligible for a leave because the employee has a serious health condition which
prevents the employee from working, the employee must present, at the time the
leave is requested, a certificate from a doctor or other health care provider
setting forth the same kinds of information as for leaves to care for a family
member, except that instead of a statement concerning the need to care for the
family member, the certificate must state why the employee is unable to perform
the functions of his/her position.  If medically necessary that an intermittent
leave be required, the doctor's or other health care provider's certificate
will also show the dates and duration of the treatment to be given.  The City
has the right to require a second opinion from an examining doctor of its own
choosing; and in the event of conflicting  opinions between the doctor who
issued the certificate and the doctor selected by the City, the City will
select a third examining doctor or other health care provider whose opinion
will be binding upon the employee and the City.  The employee and members of
the employee's family must render timely cooperation with the examining doctor
chosen by the City and with the third examining doctor or other health care
provider.  Examination fees by the City's selected doctor or other health care
provider and any third doctor will be paid by the City.  The City may require
recertification every four weeks.  The City will provide the certification
forms.
   An employee must give thirty days advance notice of a request for leave for
birth or adoption of a child or for planned medical treatment for the serious
illness of a child, spouse or parent.  If such advance notice is not possible
due to unforeseeable circumstances, the employee must give as much notice as
he/she can.  The employee will make every effort to schedule planned medical
treatment so as not to disrupt the City's operations.
   If the employee and the employee's spouse work for the City, both of them
together are entitled to only twelve weeks leave in a twelve month period to
care for a newly arried child or seriously ill parent.  Leave to care for a
newly arrived child must be taken within twelve months of the arrival of the
child.
   Health insurance and life insurance coverage will continue during the leave
under this section, under the same conditions as it would have continued had
the employee been working, including any employee premium contributions.
   At the end of a leave under this section, the employee is entitled to the
same job or one which is equivalent in terms of benefits, pay and other terms
and conditions of employment.
   The provisions of this section are to be construed so as to conform to the
Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and applicable regulations under that Act.
(Ord. 159-93.  Passed 11-16-93.)
266.07-1  PAID HOLIDAYS.
   The following shall be celebrated as paid holidays:
   The first day of January;
   The third Monday in January;
   The third Monday in February;
   The last Monday in May;
   The fourth day of July;
   The first Monday in September;
   The eleventh day in November;
   The fourth Thursday in November;
   The Friday following the fourth Thursday in November;
   The twenty-fourth day of December;
   The twenty-fifth day of December.
   (Ord. 166-2006.  Passed 8-15-06.)
266.07-2  QUALIFICATION FOR HOLIDAY PAY.
   To qualify for holiday pay a staff member must have (a) worked at least one
(1) of the last seven (7) work days immediately preceding the holiday unless on
vacation or jury duty; and (b) worked his/her last full scheduled workday
immediately preceding the holiday and next full scheduled workday following the
holiday (whether or not either qualifying day is in the same workweek as the
holiday), unless the staff member's failure to work either or both qualifying
days is due to the staff member's being on paid time off work approved in
advance by the City.  For a staff member on paid sick leave only, approval in
advance shall mean that the staff member notifies his/her supervisor of that
absence within thirty (30) minutes before the scheduled start of the staff
member's work day. 
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.07-3  HOLIDAY PAY.
   A full-time staff member shall receive the equivalent of eight (8) hours pay
for each holiday set forth above in 266.07-1, provided the staff member
qualifies for holiday pay under 266.07-2.  Less than full-time staff members
will receive seventy-five (75%) percent of full pay.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91;  Ord. 111-94.  Passed 9-20-94.)
266.07-4  WEEKEND HOLIDAYS.
   When any of the holidays specified in
266.07-1 falls on a Sunday, it shall be celebrated on the following Monday. 
When any such holiday falls on Saturday, it shall be celebrated on the
preceding Friday.  (Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.07-5  HOLIDAY DURING VACATION.
   Where a holiday occurs while a staff member who is scheduled to work that
day is on vacation, if the staff member is eligible under
266.07-2, the staff member will receive holiday pay in addition to vacation pay
for the day of the holiday. 
(Ord. 112-94.  Passed 9-20-94.)
266.08-1  VACATIONS.
   The following will be the schedule for full vacation time off and pay for
eligible staff members.
   (A)   At the end of one (1) year of employment through the end of five (5)
years of employment, a staff member will be entitled to ten (10) working days
per year.
   (B)   At the beginning of six (6) years of employment through the end of
eleven (11) years of employment, a staff member will be entitled to fifteen
(15) working days per year; if applicable, seven (7) twenty-four hour shifts
per year.
   (C)   At the beginning of twelve (12) years of employment through the end of
nineteen (19) years of employment, a staff member will be entitled to twenty
(20) working days per year; if applicable, nine (9) twenty-four hour shifts per
year.
   (D)   At the beginning of twenty (20) years of employment through the end of
twenty-six (26) years of employment, a staff member will be entitled to twenty-
five (25) working days per year; if applicable, eleven (11) twenty-four hour
shifts per year.
   (E)   At the beginning of twenty-seven (27) years of employment a staff
member will be entitled to thirty (30) working days per year; or if applicable,
twelve (12) twenty- four (24) hour shifts per year. 
      (Ord. 93-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
266.08-2  VACATION ELIGIBILITY.
   To be eligible for any paid vacation a staff member must have completed one
year of employment with the City (measured from the most recent date of hire). 
A staff member must work 2080 hours during his/her anniversary year to be
eligible for a full paid vacation.  A staff member must work at least 1040
hours, but less than 2080 hours, during his/her anniversary year to be eligible
for a pro-rated paid vacation, based upon a pro-ration formula of actual hours
worked versus 2080 hours.  For purposes of computing hours worked under this
Part and overtime or premium hours counts as one hour worked, paid time off
work on vacation and holidays shall be considered as hours worked, and paid
time off work on either sick leaves or leaves of absence up to a minimum of 120
lost work hours shall be considered as hours worked.
   The Mayor may waive the one-year of employment eligibility requirement for
newly hired Executive, Senior Administrative or Administrative Staff, in which
event the employee may be extended up to fifteen working days of vacation as
determined by the Mayor.  The Mayor, with the concurrence of a majority of
Council, may place as Executive, Senior Administrative or Administrative Staff
employee with prior qualified public service at Step B, C, or D of the vacation
schedule set forth in Section
266.08-1 based on the employee’s years of service covered under the Ohio Public
Employees Retirement System or other Ohio public employee retirement systems. 
The Mayor, with the concurrence of a majority of Council, may also place
Executive, Senior Administrative or Administrative Staff at Step B, C or D
based on year of experience substantially similar to the duties and
responsibilities set forth in the employee’s City position description for
those hired in from the private sector.
   Staff members hired after July 5, 1987, will have prior service with the
City counted for determining the amount of vacation time off and their
anniversary date will be their current Length of Service date.  Staff members
hired before July 5, 1987, will have prior service with the State of Ohio or
its political subdivisions counted for determining the amount of vacation time
and the anniversary date for those staff members will be the staff member’s
hire date with the most recent State of Ohio or political subdivision
employment prior to employment with the City.
(Ord. 132-2008.  Passed 7-29-08.)
266.08-3  VACATION SCHEDULING.
   All vacations must be taken during the anniversary year following the
anniversary year in  which they are earned.  No unused vacation will be carried
over into a subsequent anniversary year.  All vacation must be approved in
advance by the head of the division in which the staff member works, such
approval being consistent with the needs of the City with length of service
prevailing in the event of a conflict in a vacation time of two or more staff
members.  Vacation time may be used in increments of one hour or more.  Staff
members may cash out up to five days of unused vacation time. 
(Ord. 167-2006.  Passed 8-1-06.)
266.09-1  INSURANCE.
   (A)   HEALTH INSURANCE:
      (1)   The City will pay all of the cost of health insurance for full-time
staff members.
      (2)   As reflected in Section
266.01-2, certain employees are not eligible under the City’s personnel policy
for health insurance coverage and other benefits.  Regular part-time staff
members whose positions are budgeted at not less than sixty (60) hours per pay
period for the calendar year at issue are eligible to pay twenty-five percent
(25%) of the premium for a single or family policy, and the same percentage of
any premium increase, in order to provide for and maintain coverage.
      (3)   Elected officials shall be entitled to the health benefits under
the plan provided that 100% of the premiums incident to such enrollment are
paid for and by such elected officials.
         (Ord. 22-2013.  Passed 3-5-13.)
   (B)   HEALTH INSURANCE COMMITTEE.
   There is hereby established a Health Insurance Committee with authority to
negotiate health insurance coverage changes and other design modification
through consensus.
   The Committee shall consist of five (5) representatives of the City named by
the Mayor and one (1) representative of each of the City's Bargaining Units.
(Ord. 22-2010.  Passed 2-2-10.)
   (C)   LIFE AND AD&D INSURANCE:
   The City will provide term life insurance to staff members who have length
of service credit and who are on the active payroll:
      (1)   Special Support Staff - $25,000
         (Ord. 73-2000.  Passed 7-11-00.)
      (2)   Administrative Staff - Equivalent to annual wage rate based upon
2080 hours
      (3)   Senior Administrative Staff - Equivalent to 105% of annual salary
      (4)   Executive Staff - Equivalent to 110% of annual salary
   (D)   LIFE AND AD & D BENEFIT SUMMARY:
      (1)   Eligible Classes of Staff Members.  All regular full-time staff
members of the policy holder working a minimum of 30 hours each week.  The
staff members are classified as follows:
 
CLASS DESIGNATION
I     All Eligible Staff Members
      (2)   Service Waiting Period.  First of the month following one month of
continued employment.
      Staff Member Life Insurance:
      At age 70, the benefit amount is reduced to 50%.
      Waiver of Premium Continued Protection applies to this coverage.
      (3)   Accidental Death & Dismemberment Insurance.  Non-Contributory
         At age 70, the benefit amount terminates.
         (Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
   (E)   DENTAL INSURANCE:
      For the duration of this Personnel Policy, the City shall provide dental
insurance substantially equivalent to Delta Dental Plan No. 2 and Delta
Orthodontic Plan B.  (Fifty percent (50%) coverage to a total coverage of two
thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or a maximum of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00)
of orthodontic services which shall extend to staff members and spouses as well
as dependents to age nineteen (19)), for full time staff members with length of
service credit who are on the active payroll.  For single coverage, the cost of
dental insurance will be borne seventy-two and one-tenth percent (72.1%) by the
City and twenty-seven and nine-tenths percent (27.9%) by the staff member.  For
family coverage, the cost of dental insurance will be borne seventy-eight
percent (78%) by the City and twenty-two percent (22%) by the staff member.
(Ord. 96-2009.  Passed 5-5-09.)

passed June 3, 1997.)
 
   (G)   OPTICAL REIMBURSEMENT:
      In the period July 1, 2015 to June 31, 2018 and upon appropriate
documentation of the expense by an employee, the City will reimburse an
employee an amount not to exceed four hundred twenty-five dollars ($425.00) per
employee household, to cover the cost of examination, lenses, frames or contact
lenses for staff members, spouses and dependents living in the household to age
eighteen. 
(Ord. 121-2015. Passed 12-15-15.)

passed June 3, 1997.)
 
   (I)   HEALTH CARE BENEFITS.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  Former subsection I. was repealed by Ordinance 78-97,
passed June 3, 1997.)
266.09-2  PAID SICK LEAVE.
   A.   A staff member shall accumulate sick leave at the rate of .0577 hours
for each hour worked, not to exceed a total of 120 hours in an employee's
anniversary year.  For purposes of
266.09-2, paid time off work for vacation; holidays; bereavement; jury duty;
annual temporary active military status; and non-workers compensable sickness,
accident, disability and pregnancy leaves up to thirty (30) days per calendar
year shall be counted as time worked for purposes of calculating accrued sick
leave.  Except where sick leave accrued from previous employment is credited to
a staff member as required by law, a newly hired staff member shall be advanced
the equivalent of 48 hours of sick leave and will earn no further sick leave
until the initial advancement has been accumulated in accordance with the
formula set forth in this
266.09-2.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
   B.    Accumulated, but unused, sick pay may be used by the employee because
of personal illness, accident or disability (including pregnancy of the
employee) or FMLA qualifying illness in accordance with Sections
266.06-1,
266.06-6 and
266.09-3 of this chapter.  Paid sick leave cannot be used for any period of
time for which any other paid absence was requested or denied.  Sick pay will
not be used for the purpose of attending workers’ compensation hearings or
appeals.  Up to seven work days, per calendar year, of accumulated, unused sick
pay may be used because of non-FMLA qualifying illness or injury in the
employee’s immediate family.  The City may extend this use in its sole
discretion and its decision shall not be subject to the dispute procedure of
this chapter.  For non-FMLA purposes, immediate family shall mean spouse,
child, parent, brother or sister or an individual whose relationship to the
employee is equivalent to one of these categories.  Up to fifteen days of
accumulated, unused sick pay may be used as parental leave by an employee
following the delivery of the employee’s child or following the day of adoption
of a child by such employee.  Said use of sick pay shall be charged against
eligibility for family medical leave under Section
266.06-7 of this chapter.  Sick pay may not be used for an absence due to an
injury or illness arising out of or in the course of employment with another
employer where such injury or illness is compensated by workers’ compensation. 
The most recent sick pay earned will be first to be used.
(Ord. 122-2015.  Passed 12-15-15.)
   C.   A staff member may be required to furnish written documentation
satisfactory to the City to justify the use of sick leave.  Falsification of
any required justification for use of sick leave may be grounds for separation
from employment. 
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-16-93.)
   D.   An employee may continue to accumulate unused sick pay without limit. 
Upon normal retirement under the appropriate State of Ohio retirement system
after ten years of credited service (except for disability retirements which
will not require credited service minimum) or upon death, or upon termination
of employment, other than for disciplinary reasons, after fifteen years of
service with the City of Perrysburg, an employee will be paid for accumulated,
unused sick pay as follows:
      (1)   An employee will be paid for one-half (½) of the sick pay accrued
and unused prior to September 14, 1976, not to exceed a total of 720 hours.
      (2)   An employee will be paid for one-fourth (1/4) the first 1000 hours
of sick  pay accrued and unused or on after September 14, 1976, one-half of the
next 1250 hours of accrued and unused sick pay minus any hours of sick pay
accrued and unused prior to September 14, 1976, and all of the next 125 hours
of accrued and unused sick pay for an aggregate total not to exceed 1000
hours. 
(Ord. 170-2006.  Passed 8-1-06.)
   E.   Use of sick leave shall be calculated based upon the number of work
hours a staff member was absent during the staff member's normal work day. 
Sick leave may be used in one-half (1/2) hour increments.  (Ord. 105-91. 
Passed 11-5-91.)
   F.   Paid sick leave cannot be used for any period of time for which any
other paid absence was requested and denied. 
(Ord. 75-2000.  Passed 7-11-00.)
266.09-3  ACCIDENT COMPENSATION.
   (A)   A staff member injured while at work for the City through no fault of
his/her own and not in violation of City safety rules, regulations or practices
and who is unable to perform his/her regular job duties will receive his/her
regular base pay for up to one (1) year.  Accident compensation will be
available for Workers’ Compensation leaves under Section
266.06-7 of this Personnel Policy.  (Ord. 98-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
   (B)   To be qualified for accident compensation or continued accident
compensation, the City may require the same types of proof of continuing
disability as are required for sickness, accident or disability leave under
266.09-1 or
 266.09-7, whichever is applicable.
(Ord. 159-93.  Passed 11-16-93.)
   (C)   The City may, at its option, require the staff member to be assigned
other duties during the period he/she is disabled, provided he/she is capable
of performing those duties, in the opinion of a physician.  Said temporary
assignment shall not be for more than one (1) year measured from the first day
of the disability and the employee shall receive his her regular rate of pay
during the temporary assignment.
   (D)   In the event the disability is determined to be permanent, in the
opinion of a physician, the staff member shall avail himself/herself of the
disability benefits provided by the State Workers’ Compensation Law and the
appropriate retirement system.
(Ord. 98-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
266.09-4  RETIREMENT BENEFITS.
   A staff member covered by this Personnel Policy shall continue to
participate in the appropriate Ohio Public Employee Retirement System.  Each
staff member's mandatory contribution to the retirement system shall be
designated as "picked up" by the City as contemplated by Internal Revenue
Service Rulings 77-462 and 81-36, although they shall continue to be designated
as staff member contributions as permitted by Attorney General Opinion 82-097,
in order that the amount of the staff member's income reported by the Board as
subject to federal and Ohio income tax shall be the staff member's total gross
income reduced by their current percentage amount of the staff member's
mandatory retirement system contribution which has been designated as "picked
up" by the City, and that the amount designated as "picked up" by the City
shall be included in computing final average salary, provided that no staff
member's total salary is increased by such "pick up", nor is the City's total
contribution to the applicable retirement system increased thereby.  The above
language shall be applicable to the Police Relief and Pension Fund and the Ohio
Fire Relief and Pension Fund and to the Ohio Public Employee Retirement System.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.09-5  DEFERRED COMPENSATION.
   A.   PROGRAM - 1 (OPEDC):
   All eligible staff members of the City shall have the opportunity to join
the Ohio Public Employees Deferred Compensation Program.  The Mayor and City
Clerk shall execute an agreement with the Ohio Public Employees Deferred
Compensation Board on terms and conditions in the best interest of the City,
which agreement shall authorize the Ohio Public Employees Deferred Compensation
Board to offer the Program to include all eligible staff members of the City
and to administer the Program on behalf of them.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
   B.   CITY CONTRIBUTION LIMITS FOR DEFERRED COMPENSATION - PROGRAM 2:
   The City shall contribute to Deferred Compensation - Program 2, a monthly
amount as follows:
      (1)   Administrative Staff Member, City Inspector and Executive Secretary
- An amount equal to staff member's voluntary contribution not to exceed three
percent (3%) of annual wage rate.
         (Ord. 149-2006.  Passed 6-20-06.)
      (2)   Senior Administrative Staff Member and Human Resources Manager and
Tax Administrator - An amount not to exceed six percent (6%) of the annual
salary.
      (3)   Executive Staff Member - An amount not to exceed six percent (6%)
of the annual salary or wage rate.
   The annual wage rate will be based upon 2080 hours.
(Ord. 76-2000.  Passed 7-11-00; Ord.  14-01.  Passed 1-16-01; Ord. 10-2003. 
Passed 2-4-03.)
   C.   DEFERRED COMPENSATION BENEFITS - PROGRAM - 2:
   Benefits shall be paid to the staff member or the staff member’s named
beneficiary in the event of death, disability, or separation from service in
accordance with the terms of the Ohio Municipal League Master Deferred
Compensation Program and applicable Federal law.
(Ord. 52-2007.  Passed 4-17-07.)
   D.   DEFERRED COMPENSATION - PROGRAM - 2 - VESTING. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S  NOTE:  Former Subsection D. hereof was repealed by Ordinance 53-
2007, passed April 17, 2007.
   E.   DEFERRED COMPENSATION - PROGRAM - 2 - EMERGENCY WITHDRAWALS.
   Withdrawals for the emergency needs of a covered staff member may be made in
accordance with the terms of the Ohio Municipal League Master Deferred 
Compensation Program and applicable Federal law. 
(Ord. 54-2007.  Passed 4-17-07.)
266.09-6  REPLACEMENT PAY.
   Where a Senior Administrative Staff member is absent for five (5) or more
consecutive work days, the Administrative Staff member assigned to perform his/
her duties during such absence will be paid three dollars ($3.00) per hour in
addition to the Administrative Staff member’s regular hourly pay.  This section
shall not be effective on or after March 1, 2008.
(Ord. 74-2007.  Passed  5-1-07.)
266.09-7  EXTENDED SICK LEAVE.
   In addition to the sick leave advanced to newly hired staff members in
accordance with
266.09-2, Senior Administrative Staff members, the Tax Administrator and the
Human Resources Manager shall be advanced up to 472 hours of extended sick
leave upon hire.  After the staff member accumulates the initial 48 hours of
sick leave in accordance with 
266.09-2, additional sick leave accumulations will reduce the amount of the
extended sick leave advancement such that the sum of a staff member’s
accumulated sick leave and extended sick leave shall always total 520 hours
before deducting any sick leave or extended sick leave usage.  Upon a staff
member accumulating 520 hours of sick leave, all further sick leave
accumulations shall be in accordance with
266.09-2 and this section will no longer apply.
   Eligible staff members may use extended sick leave because of personal
illness, accident or disability (including pregnancy of the staff member) in
accordance with
266.06-1 ,
 266-06-7  and
266.09-3  of this Personnel Policy.  Extended sick leave may only be used when
all accrued sick leave and vacation time have been exhausted.  The staff member
must continue to pay the staff member’s share of health and dental insurance
premiums.  All time used under this provision will run concurrently with Family
and Medical Leaves provided under
266.06-7.
   (A)   TOTAL DISABILITY (ILLNESS OR NON-WORK RELATED INJURY).  An eligible
staff member shall receive sixty percent (60%) of their bi-weekly salary.
   (B)   PARTIAL DISABILITY (WORKING INTERMITTENTLY OR PART-TIME DUE TO ILLNESS
OR NON-WORK RELATED INJURY).  An eligible staff member shall receive sixty
percent (60%) of their lost wages when they are absent.  (For example, if a
staff member works half-days, they would receive 60% of the lost 50%, or if a
staff member works three (3) days per week, they would receive 60% of the lost
40%).
      (Ord. 99-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
266.10-1  SAVINGS CLAUSE.
   It is the intention of the City that the provisions of this Personnel Policy
conform to applicable federal, State or local law.  If any provision of this
Personnel Policy violates any federal, State or local laws as presently enacted
or enacted or amended during the term of this Personnel Policy, such provision
shall be inoperative to the extent that it is at variance with such law, but
all remaining provisions of this Personnel Policy shall remain in full force
and effect.  In order to comply with the maximum number of straight time hours
a staff member may work during a given period of time or for other reasons
under applicable federal and/or State law, the work hours and schedule of each
staff member may be altered or otherwise determined by the City.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.10-2  ADDRESSES/PHONE NUMBERS.
   For purposes of this Personnel Policy, it shall be the sole responsibility
of each staff member to inform the City in writing of the staff member's
current address and current telephone numbers (home and cell) at which he/she
can be reached within five (5) working days following the effective date of
this Personnel Policy and thereafter within five (5) working days of any change
in either address or telephone number.  The City shall provide forms for such
changes.  The change form shall be delivered to the Office of the Mayor and the
City shall change the staff member's records, and file a copy of the form in
the staff member's personnel file.  The City shall have a right to rely upon
the most current address and telephone number for a staff member as shown on
the City records.
(Ord. 123-2015.  Passed 12-15-15.)
266.10-3  NONDISCRIMINATION.
   The City shall not unlawfully discriminate against any staff member because
of race, creed, color, sex, age, religion or handicap.  Because of the
existence of adequate federal and State remedial procedures, alleged violations
of 266.10-3 shall be referable to Step 3 of the Dispute Settlement Procedure
but not to arbitration.
   All references to staff member(s) in this Personnel Policy designate both
sexes.
   Nothing contained in this Personnel Policy shall prevent the City from
complying with applicable State or federal laws governing  handicap or
disability.
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.10-4  PAY PERIODS.
   Pay periods for all staff members shall be biweekly.  Pay days shall be
every other Friday, unless the selected Friday falls on a holiday on which
staff members do not normally work or for which staff members are given
compensatory time off.  In such event, pay day shall be on the first regular
workday preceding such holiday. 
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.10-5  PRE-EMPLOYMENT MEDICAL EXAMINATION.
   Each person, prior to beginning work for the City, shall be required to
undergo a medical examination by an examining physician or physicians selected
by the Mayor.  The medical examiner shall report and certify to the Mayor
whether such person is physically and mentally capable of performing the
services required of the position to which he/she is being appointed.  The
medical examination shall be at the expense of the City.  If the medical
examiner reports that such person in not physically and/or mentally capable of
performing the service required of the position to which he is being appointed,
then such person is not eligible for employment with the City in that
position. 
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
266.10-6  ATTENDANCE AT CONFERENCES.
   Staff members authorized or directed by the Mayor or City Administrator at
attend a conference, convention, school, seminar, workshop or other training or
educational function relating to the staff member’s duty assignment or other
function of municipal concern will be reimbursed for the staff member’s
reasonable and necessary expenses incurred, such as registration fees and
tuition, meals, lodging, gratuities, vehicle parking, tolls and common carrier
fares.  Reimbursement for meals and gratuities for meals will be as adopted by
the current Federal Travel Regulation of the General Services Administration
current meal rates by location; provided that if the conference encompasses the
period of more than the meal, the per meal allowance may be aggregated so long
as the total does not exceed the sum of the totals permitted for the meals
encompassed or the daily maximum, whichever is less; and provided further that
there shall be no reimbursement for the cost of any alcoholic beverages.  When
travel is directed in the staff member’s own vehicle, the staff member will be
reimbursed at the rate per mile as authorized by the State of Ohio at the time
of travel.  No reimbursement will be made without proof or certification of
such expenditure submitted with the staff member’s claim for reimbursement. 
When payment in advance of attendance and travel is authorized by the Mayor or
City Administrator, any amount due and owing the City by the staff member shall
be repaid to the City upon the staff member’s completion of attendance and
travel.  Staff members will not be compensated for hours of attendance at the
foregoing functions unless they were otherwise scheduled to work those hours or
their supervisor authorizes the pay in writing in advance of the function. 
(Ord. 100-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
266.10-7  UNIFORMS.
   A.   STREET, WATER AND WATER POLLUTION CONTROL UNIFORMS:
   The City shall provide work uniforms for a staff member normally involved in
outside activities in the Department of Public Service and the Department of
Public Utilities.  The uniform shall consist of pants and a shirt or
coveralls.  During June, July and August three pant and five shirt changes per
week shall be provided.  Foul weather gear will be made available by the City. 
All uniforms provided pursuant to Section
266.10-7 shall be kept in acceptable condition and must be returned to the City
when the staff member’s employment with the City is voluntarily or
involuntarily terminated, or when such uniforms are no longer required to be
worn by the employee.  Failure of a staff member to comply with the
requirements of the preceding sentence shall be cause for deducting the
reasonable value of uniform items from moneys otherwise due the staff member. 
Staff members must wear acceptable clothing and are required to wear their
uniforms. 
(Ord. 35-2012.  Passed 3-6-12.)
   B.   FIRE DIVISION UNIFORMS:
   The City shall establish a uniform account for each full time Fire Division
staff member covered by this Personnel Policy, for the purchase, alteration,
and/or repair of approved uniforms consisting of a jacket/coat, shirt, tie,
cap, shoes and skirt or slacks.  Uniform accounts shall not be used to pay for
normal cleaning and laundry expenses.  The City shall deposit nine hundred
fifty dollars ($950.00) in the account of each staff member at the time of
hire.  In each calendar year thereafter the City shall deposit six hundred
seventy-five dollars ($675.00) in the account of each staff member.  In
addition the City shall pay up to two hundred seventy-five dollars ($275.00)
for the purchase of Class A uniform for each staff member hired on and after
March 1, 1994.
   C.   POLICE DIVISION UNIFORMS:
   The City shall establish a uniform account for each sworn staff member of
the Police Division covered by this Personnel Policy for the purchase,
alteration and/or repair of approved uniform consisting of a jacket/coat,
shirt, tie, cap, shoes and skirt or slacks.  Uniform accounts shall not be used
to pay for normal cleaning and laundry expenses.  The City shall deposit nine
hundred dollars ($900.00) in the account of each staff member at the time of
hire and forty-one and 66/100 dollars per month in the account for each
remaining month of the calendar year.  In each calendar year thereafter the
City shall deposit five hundred dollars ($500.00) in the account of each staff
member.  For duty assignments requiring additional equipment the City shall
deposit two hundred dollars ($200.00) at the outset of the assignment and an
additional one hundred dollars ($100.00) during each year of the continuation
of the assignment in the account of each staff member.
(Ord. 101-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
   D.   UNIFORMS PROVIDED:  In lieu of the amounts of money set forth above in
Subparts B and C, the City may substitute new or used uniform items, the fair
value (reasonable alteration costs, straight line depreciation based on
original cost and expected life of new items, and allowance for unusual wear)
shall be deducted from the amounts set forth above for such staff members. 
(Ord. 105-91.  Passed 11-5-91.)
   E.   UNIFORMS GENERALLY:
   All expenditures under the provisions of this Subparts B,C, and D must be
authorized by the Chief of Police or the Fire Chief and the Safety Director
with payment in all cases being made by the City directly to the vendor
supplying the uniform item or services in connection therewith.  The balance of
each individual account will be carried over each year and the balance of any
individual account will be turned over to the City’s General Fund when a staff
member leaves employment of the Police Division or Fire Division, all uniforms
provided or purchases pursuant to this Part shall be kept in acceptable
condition and must be returned to the City when the staff member’s employment
with the Police Division or Fire Division is voluntarily or involuntarily
terminated.  Failure of a staff member to comply with the requirements of the
preceding sentence shall be cause for deducting the reasonable value of the
uniform items from moneys otherwise due the staff member. 
(Ord. 110-2003.  Passed 6-17-03.)
   F.   UNIFORM CLEANING:
   A two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per contract year uniform cleaning
allowance shall be established for each full-time staff member of the Police
Division and Fire Division covered by this Personnel Policy.  Less than full
time staff members will receive seventy-five percent (75%) of the full time
staff member cleaning allowance.
(Ord. 172-2006.  Passed 8-1-06.)
   G.   SAFETY GLASSES AND SHOES:
   The City will permit staff members in the Street, Water and Water Pollution
Control Divisions, City Inspectors and Engineering Technicians, to purchase
prescription safety glasses (safety glasses must meet ANSIZ 87.1 requirements)
and safety shoes at whatever cost saving the City is able to obtain from
vendors and shall pay up to one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) per staff
member, per year, toward the purchase of OSHA complaint safety shoes and
uniform outerwear to be determined at the division level and to be purchased
from a single source, bearing the staff member name and the City logo visible
at  all times.  Such uniform items shall not be used except on duty and to and
from home and commute-related incidental activities.  Uniform outerwear shall
only be provided if the items are necessary for the performance of the duties
of the staff members job for the City.  Reimbursement shall only be paid upon
presentation of an original receipt.  (Ord. 173-2006.  Passed 8-1-06.)
