804.01  APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall control the licensing of the various
trades, businesses and professions regulated by this Business Regulation Code,
except to the extent that such licensing is regulated in subsequent chapters in
this Business Regulation Code. As used in this section and throughout the
Codified Ordinances, "Business Regulation Code" means Title Two - Business
Regulation of Part Eight - the Business Regulation and Taxation Code.
(1964 Code Sec. 701.01)
804.02  LICENSES FOR TRADES, BUSINESSES OR PROFESSIONS.
   No person shall engage in any of the trades, businesses or professions for
which licenses are required by this Title Two - Business Regulation of Part
Eight - the Business Regulation and Taxation Code, or by any other ordinance or
provision of the Codified Ordinances, without first applying for and obtaining
a license from the Municipal Clerk or other duly authorized issuing authority.
(1964 Code Sec. 701.01)
804.03  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   All original applications for licenses, unless otherwise specifically
provided, shall be made to the Municipal Clerk in writing upon forms to be
furnished by him and shall contain:
   (a)    The name of the applicant and of each officer, partner or business
associate;
   (b)    His present occupation and place of business;
   (c)    His place of residence for five years next preceding the date of
application;
   (d)    The nature and location of the intended business or enterprise;
   (e)    The period of time for which the license is desired;
   (f)    If for a vendor, a description of the merchandise to be sold; and
   (g)   Such other information concerning the applicant and his business as
may be reasonable and proper, having regard to the nature of the license
desired.
   Renewal of an annual license may be granted to a licensee in good standing
upon the original application, unless otherwise provided.
   With each original or renewal application, the applicant shall deposit the
fee required for the license requested.
   No person shall knowingly make any false statement or representation in such
application. (1964 Code Sec. 701.02)
804.04  LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   Upon receipt of such application for a license, accompanied by the proper
fee, if approval by another officer or department is not required, the
Municipal Clerk, by and with the approval of the Mayor, shall forthwith deposit
the fee in the Treasury and issue to the applicant a proper license certificate
signed by the Clerk and Mayor. If for any reason the license is not issued, the
aforesaid deposit, less one dollar ($1.00) to cover expenses of considering
such application, shall be returned to the applicant. (1964 Code Sec. 701.03)
804.05  LICENSE DATE AND DURATION.
   A license shall not be valid beyond the expiration date therein specified
and, unless otherwise provided, shall not extend beyond December 31 of the year
issued. However, at any time after December 14, licenses may be issued for the
ensuing calendar year. Unless otherwise specified, the full annual fee will be
required for licenses irrespective of the date of issue of such licenses.
(1964 Code Sec. 701.04)
804.06  LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY.
   Every license shall be issued to a real party in interest in the enterprise
or business and, unless otherwise provided, no license shall be assigned or
transferred.
(1964 Code Sec. 701.05)
804.07  LICENSE DISPLAY OR EXHIBITION.
   Every licensee carrying on business at a fixed location shall keep posted in
a prominent place upon the licensed premises the license certificate. Other
licensees shall carry their license certificates at all times and shall exhibit
the same whenever requested by any officer or resident of the City. (1964 Code
Sec. 701.06)
804.08  LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
   Any license may be revoked by the Mayor at any time for conditions or
considerations which, had they existed at the time of issuance, would have been
valid grounds for its denial; for any misrepresentation of a material fact in
the application discovered after issuance of the license; for violation of any
provision of this Business Regulation Code or other law or ordinance relating
to the operation of the business or enterprise for which the license has been
issued; or for conviction of a licensee for a violation of any Federal, State
or municipal law or ordinance involving moral turpitude. Such revocation shall
become effective upon notice served upon such licensee or posted upon the
premises affected.
   As a preliminary to revocation, the Mayor may issue an order suspending such
license, which order shall become effective immediately upon service of written
notice to such licensee. Such notice shall specify the reason for suspension
and may provide conditions under which reinstatement of the license may be
obtained. Upon compliance with such conditions within the time specified, such
license may be restored. (1964 Code Sec. 701.07)
804.09  APPEAL AND REVIEW.
   In case any applicant has been denied a license, or if his license has been
revoked or suspended, the applicant or licensee, as the case may be, shall,
within three business days, have the right to appeal to Council from such
denial, revocation or suspension. Notice of appeal shall be filed in writing
with the Municipal Clerk who shall fix the time and place for hearing, which
hearing shall be not later than one week thereafter. The Clerk shall notify the
Mayor and all members of Council of the time and place of such hearing not less
than twelve hours in advance thereof. Three members of Council shall constitute
a quorum to hear such appeal. The appellant may appear and be heard in person
or by counsel. If, after hearing, a majority of the members of Council present
at such meeting declare in favor of the applicant, such license shall be
forthwith issued or fully reinstated as the case may be; otherwise the order
appealed from shall be final. (1964 Code Sec. 701.08)
804.99  GENERAL CODE PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
Business Regulation Code, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty
of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars
($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 808
Auctioneers (Repealed)
   EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter was repealed as part of the 1988 updating and
revision of these Codified Ordinances because Ohio R.C. 4707.111 prohibits
municipalities from regulating auctioneers and auction sales.
CHAPTER 812
Bail Bondsmen
812.01   Compliance with regulations.
812.02   Registration and qualifications.
812.03   Maximum charges.
812.04   Charges to be total.
812.05   Receipt issuance and delivery.
812.06   Posting of fee schedule.
812.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Bail provisions in civil action - see Ohio R.C. 2713.03, 2713.09 et seq.
Bail provisions in criminal cases - see Ohio R.C. 2937.21 et seq.
 
812.01  COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS.
   Every person proposing to furnish bond or other security for the bail of any
person accused of any offense before the Municipal Court of Perrysburg, for
which service a charge is proposed to be made to any person, shall be permitted
to do so and shall be regulated in so doing in accordance with the provisions
of the following sections hereof.
(Ord. 510-59. Passed 3-24-59.)
812.02  REGISTRATION AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   Any such person shall first register with the Police Chief, providing such
information as shall be reasonably required in connection with such business
and, further, shall submit to the Solicitor for his approval, evidence of such
person's qualifications to conduct such business.
(Ord. 510-59. Passed 3-24-59.)
812.03  MAXIMUM CHARGES.
   Any such person shall be limited to the following charges for the furnishing
of bond or security for bail:
   (a)    For a bond of $25.00 or less, a maximum fee of $5.00;
   (b)    For a bond not exceeding $50.00, but more than $25.00, a maximum fee
of $7.50;
   (c)    For a bond not exceeding $100.00, but more than $50.00, a maximum fee
of $10.00;
   (d)    For a bond exceeding $100.00, a maximum fee of ten percent of the
amount of the bond. (Ord. 510-59. Passed 3-24-59.)
812.04  CHARGES TO BE TOTAL.
   The aforesaid schedule of charges shall be the total charges made for such
service and shall include attorney fees and all other expenses incurred by the
bondsman incident to the furnishing of bail. (Ord. 510-59. Passed 3-24-59.)
812.05  RECEIPT ISSUANCE AND DELIVERY.
   For all fees so paid such person shall prepare in triplicate a receipt of
the charges, one copy of which shall be given to the person paying the same,
one copy of which shall be delivered to the Chief of Police and the other copy
shall be retained by such person, as part of his permanent records. The receipt
shall be issued and delivered within forty-eight hours after the fee is paid.
The form of the receipt shall be approved by the Police Chief.
(Ord. 510-59. Passed 3-24-59.)
812.06  POSTING OF FEE SCHEDULE.
   Notice of the schedule of fees set forth in Section
812.03 shall be posted in one or more conspicuous places in the Police Station
and in the Municipal Court, as designated by the Police Chief.
(Ord. 510-59. Passed 3-24-59.)
812.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both, for each
offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each fee charged for
a bail bond in excess of the amount set forth in Section
812.03.
CHAPTER 813
Mobile Food Vehicles
813.01   Definitions.
813.02   Registration required.
813.03   Application for registration.
813.04   Furnishing of information.
813.05   Permit.
813.06   Enforcement and penalty.
813.01  DEFINITIONS.
   The following terms shall have the following meanings when used in this
chapter:
   (a)    The City Administrator shall mean the City Administrator of the City
of Perrysburg.
   (b)    The Tax Administrator shall mean the Income Tax Commissioner of the
City of Perrysburg.
   (c)    Food Establishment shall mean a business operation or any part
thereof that stores, prepares, packages, serves, vends or otherwise provides
food and/or beverages for human consumption.
   (d)    Mobile Food Vehicle shall mean a Food Establishment that is located
upon a vehicle including motorcycles and bicycles, or which is pulled by a
vehicle.  This definition includes mobile food kitchens, pushcart vendors,
bicycle cart vendors, mobile food trucks, canteen trucks and coffee trucks.
   (e)     Mobile Food Vehicle Operator shall mean any and all persons
associated with the operation of a Mobile Food Vehicle for which registration
has been made to operate the Mobile Food Vehicle within the City.
      (Ord. 52-2017.  Passed 8-1-17.)
813.02  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   Except as provided in
813.03(c), no Mobile Food Vehicle shall be operated in the City without first
registering with the City Administrator. A separate registration must be made
for each and every Mobile Food Vehicle to be operated within the City.
(Ord. 52-2017.  Passed 8-1-17.)
813.03  APPLICATION FOR REGISTRATION.
   (a)   Each Mobile Food Vehicle operator shall, prior to commencing
operations within the City, furnish the City Administrator, on a form provided
by the City, a fully executed application for registration to operate a Mobile
Food Vehicle within the City.
   (b)   Applications for registrations to operate Mobile Food Vehicles will be
accepted by the City Administrator each year beginning March 1.
   (c)   Mobile Food Vehicles operating within the boundaries of the City,
stopping, standing or otherwise parking in the public right of way for only 15
consecutive minutes or less, shall not be required to apply for registration to
operate a Mobile Food Vehicle within the boundaries of the City in the public
right of way.
(Ord. 52-2017.  Passed 8-1-17.)
813.04  FURNISHING OF INFORMATION.
   A Mobile Food Vehicle Operator, prior to commencing Mobile Food Vehicle
operations within the City, shall furnish the City Administrator with the
following documents and information:
     (a)     A current, written certification that the Mobile Food Vehicle has
passed all necessary inspections required by the City Fire Department;
   (b)     A current written certification that the Mobile Food Vehicle
Operator and the Mobile Food Vehicle have passed all necessary inspections and
are in full compliance with the Wood County Health Department;
   (c)     A letter of good standing from the City Income Tax Division with
respect to the Mobile Food Vehicle operations; and
   (d)     A current certificate of insurance evidencing general liability
coverage in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) in the
aggregate in a form acceptable to the City.
      (Ord. 52-2017.  Passed 8-1-17.)
813.05  PERMIT.
   (a)     Each Mobile Food Vehicle Operator shall, prior to commencing
operations within the City, pay an annual, nonrefundable permit fee to the City
Administr   ator in the amount of $100.00.
   (b)    The City shall, no later than 14 days after receiving (i) a fully
executed application for registration to operate a Mobile Food Vehicle within
the City, (ii) all other required documents and information, and (iii) an
annual permit fee, issue a permit to the Mobile Food Vehicle Operator to
operate the Mobile Food Vehicle within the City.
   (c)     Mobile Food Vehicle permits must be on display, on the vehicle, in
full sight for all to see at all times while the Mobile Food Vehicle is
operating within the City.
   (d)     Mobile Food Vehicle permits are specific to the Mobile Food Vehicle
Operator and the Mobile Food Vehicle.
   (e)     Mobile Food Vehicle permits will automatically expire each year on
December 31.
   (f)     No annual permit fee shall be required of Mobile Food Vehicles or
Mobile Food Vehicle Operators owned or compensated by a food establishment
currently operating within the boundaries of the City, from a fixed location
(i.e., from owned or leased real property), and in compliance with all other
applicable, local regulations.
(Ord. 52-2017.  Passed 8-1-17.)
813.06  ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTY. 
    In the case of a failure by any Mobile Food Vehicle Operator to comply with
any of the provisions of this chapter, such Mobile Food Vehicle Operator shall
be in violation and shall be subject to a penalty.
   (a)   The provisions of this section shall be enforceable by the Perrysburg
Police Division.
   (b)   A penalty in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be
assessed and immediately payable for failure to comply with any of the
provisions of this chapter.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day, or part thereof, for which a Mobile Food Vehicle Operator fails to comply
with any of the provisions of this chapter.  Any and all penalties are in
addition to the annual permit fee.
   (c)   No penalty shall be imposed under this chapter with respect to any
failure if it is shown that such failure is due to reasonable cause and not to
willfull neglect.
   (d)   Upon discovery of the violation, the Mobile Food Vehicle operator
shall be served with notice of violation and demand for penalty in the same
manner as a fine.  Upon service with the notice of violation, the Mobile Food
Vehicle operator shall immediately cease operations within the City of
Perrysburg until such time as the Mobile Food Vehicle operator is issued a
valid permit for operations.
   (e)   No Mobile Food Vehicle Operator shall be permitted to operate a Mobile
Food Vehicle within the City for any year in which it has been assessed
penalties under this chapter on more than two occasions.
      (Ord. 22-2019.  Passed 6-4-19.)

CHAPTER 820
Circuses, Carnivals and Amusement Rides
820.01   License required; location and  duration.
820.02   Deposit required.
820.03   License fee.
820.04   Fee waiver in civic interest.
820.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.48, 715.63, 3765.02
Contests or games at county fairs - see Ohio R.C. 1711.09, 1711.11
County license for public shows - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3765
Pandering obscenity - see GEN. OFF.
666.12
 
820.01  LICENSE REQUIRED; LOCATION AND DURATION.
   Each person desiring to conduct, stage or give a circus, carnival, sideshow
or amusement rides for which money or reward is demanded or received shall
first obtain a license and pay the license fee or fees provided herein.
   The applicant for a license to conduct, stage or give such exhibition shall
give at least one week's notice in writing to the Mayor, stating the dates of
the performances and the location at which they are to be presented. The Mayor
shall give his consent to the issuance of such license if he deems the location
suitable for the purpose, that it will properly accommodate the patrons, that
the nature of the performance or exhibition is morally proper, and that the use
of such location will not throw too great a burden upon the Police and Fire
Divisions.
   No circus, carnival, sideshow or amusement rides shall be given for more
than two consecutive days, except in cases where Council by special resolution
shall allow a longer period, or where such exhibition is to be conducted on
Municipal property and the use thereof for a longer period shall have been
approved by Council. (Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
820.02  DEPOSIT REQUIRED.
   At the time such application for a license is made, and use of Municipal
grounds or public streets or thoroughfares is contemplated, the applicant shall
deposit with the Municipal Clerk a cash bond of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
in the case of carnivals or shows during which no animals perform or are
exhibited, and two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) with respect to circuses or
similar shows during which animals perform or are exhibited or which, in the
opinion of the Mayor, involve an unusual burden or likelihood of creating
problems of public safety, public health, cleanliness or destruction of
property. In any event the deposit shall be conditioned upon the restoration
and cleaning up of the grounds used and the proper conducting and management of
the shows in the best public interest in a manner found satisfactory by the
Mayor. In the event the grounds shall be restored and cleaned up properly and
promptly following the exhibition, and all other conditions imposed with
respect to the deposit have been observed, the deposit shall be returned.
Otherwise, the deposit, or that part thereof determined by the Mayor to provide
adequate compensation for the nonperformance of the conditions upon which the
deposit was made, shall be forfeited to the City.
(1964 Code Sec. 713.02)
820.03  LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for such license shall be as follows: for each circus, carnival,
sideshow or amusement rides, fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first day and
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each day thereafter. However, such fee shall
not amount to more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) in any one week.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
820.04  FEE WAIVER IN CIVIC INTEREST.
   The Mayor may, in his discretion, grant without cost a license for the
holding of a circus, carnival, sideshow or amusement rides for not more than
six consecutive days, where all of the performances are fostered and supervised
by civic interests of the City, and a substantial part of the funds derived
therefrom is expended for charitable or civic purposes.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
820.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 824
Community Antenna Television Systems
824.01   Definitions.
824.02   Broadcast regulations; requirements.
824.03   Program approval.
824.04   Compulsory service to schools; City.
824.05   Sale or repair limited to own facilities.
824.06   Use of poles, towers for construction.
824.07   Indemnity to City, required.
824.08   Bonds and insurance.
824.09   Interference with existing communications.
824.10   Operation fee.
824.11   Service standards required.
824.12   Pay television prohibited.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Franchises - see CHTR. Art.
 XIII
 
824.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    The term "community antenna television system," wherever used in this
chapter, includes community antenna television and the receipt, transmission
and distribution of voices, sounds, signals, pictures, visual images or any
other type of closed circuit transmission or signal transmission by means of
electrical impulses.
   (b)    The term "applicant" means any person, firm, corporation or
association engaged in the community antenna television business. (Ord. 2-66.
Passed 1-11-66.)
824.02  BROADCAST REGULATIONS; REQUIREMENTS.
   The applicant shall, upon request of any commercial television station
located within the corporate limits of the City or any city in Lucas or Wood
Counties wherein the applicant has a permit to provide community antenna
television service (herein called the local television station), distribute
without change or degradation the requested programs of such local television
station. Any program which the applicant carries from any television station
shall be carried in its entirety and without change. The applicant, upon
request of any local television station, shall not simultaneously duplicate the
programming of such local television station by the distribution of a signal of
a nonlocal station. The applicant shall provide a local service channel for
weather information, time, public service announcements and background music.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.03  PROGRAM APPROVAL.
   Except as otherwise herein provided, the applicant shall originate no
programs without securing in advance the approval of City Council or its agent
designated for such purpose.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.04  COMPULSORY SERVICE TO SCHOOLS; CITY.
   The applicant shall reserve one channel for educational programming, and
shall furnish, without charge, one connection for each public and parochial
school, including colleges and universities, located in areas served by the
communications system, and shall furnish without charge monthly service
thereafter for so long as such communications system remains in operation in
the area. Any such school may install at its expense such additional
connections for classroom purposes as it desires, provided that such
installation shall not interfere with the operation of the applicant's system,
and that the quality and manner of installation of such additional connections
shall have been approved by the applicant and shall comply with all City, State
and Federal laws and regulations. In addition, the applicant shall furnish to
the City without charge such connections as may be required for regulation and
supervision of the communications system, not to exceed three, and shall
provide without charge monthly service thereafter, provided that such
connections are located in public buildings in areas being served by the
communications system.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.05  SALE OR REPAIR LIMITED TO OWNED FACILITIES.
   The applicant shall not engage in the sale, leasing, installation or repair
of television sets or television antennae, except such sets, antennae and
related facilities as may be owned by the applicant. (Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-
66.)
824.06  USE OF POLES, TOWERS FOR CONSTRUCTION.
   The applicant shall, where agreement can be reached with the owner, use
existing poles, towers or other facilities for the construction of its
facilities. All such installations by the applicant shall be subject to all
existing and future regulatory ordinances of the City.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.07  INDEMNITY TO CITY REQUIRED.
   The applicant shall indemnify, protect and save harmless the City from any
and all loss or damages arising out of claims for injury or death to any person
or persons incurred by or asserted against the City by reason of the operations
of the applicant and the grant authorized.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.08  BONDS AND INSURANCE.
   The applicant shall furnish such bonds or policies of insurance as may be
required, which shall be approved by the City Solicitor and deposited with and
kept on file in the office of the Municipal Clerk. (Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.09  INTERFERENCE WITH EXISTING COMMUNICATIONS.
   The installations and maintenance shall be such that no interference is
caused to existing communications systems so as not to distort or affect
direct-over-the-air television.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.10  OPERATION FEE.
   The applicant shall pay to the City three percent of gross proceeds derived
from monthly charges paid by the inhabitants of the City for services,
exclusive of attachment or installation charges, so long as the applicant owns
or utilizes facilities in the streets of such City.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.11  SERVICE STANDARDS REQUIRED.
   The applicant shall furnish to all persons living within a serviced area and
who desire the service, and pay for the same, a service capable of producing as
good a quality of television picture signal or reception as may be possible
from time to time, and shall continue to make all reasonable betterments and
improvements of such system.
(Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-66.)
824.12  PAY TELEVISION PROHIBITED.
   The applicant shall not engage in the business of pay television, that is,
the sale of programs on a program-by-program basis. (Ord. 2-66. Passed 1-11-
66.)
824.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 828
Dealers in Secondhand Articles
828.01   Dealer in secondhand articles defined.
828.02   License required.
828.03   License fees.
828.04   Record of acquisitions.
828.05   Record of sales.
828.06   Fourteen-day retention required.
828.07   Weekly report to Division of Police.
828.08   Purchase from minors prohibited.
828.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Secondhand dealers and junk yards - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
Licensing in general - see B. R. & T. Ch.
804
Peddlers, solicitors and canvassers - see B.R. & T. Ch.
852
 
828.01  DEALER IN SECONDHAND ARTICLES DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "dealer in secondhand articles" means any person
dealing in the purchase or sale of secondhand jewelry, gold, silver or other
precious metals, including antiques, or dealing in the purchase or sale of any
secondhand manufactured article, composed wholly or in part of gold, silver,
platinum or other precious metals, or in the purchase or sale of old gold,
silver, platinum or other precious metals, for the purpose of melting or
refining, or engaged in melting precious metals for the purpose of selling, or
in the sale of secondhand jewelry, gold, silver, platinum or other precious
metals taken as trade-ins on new merchandise sold by such person, or in the
purchase or sale of pawnbrokers' tickets or other evidence of pledged articles,
not being a pawnbroker, or in the redemption or sale of jewelry, gold, silver,
platinum or other precious metals or other pledged articles of like kind.
(Ord. 25-81. Passed 4-14-81.)
828.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person shall engage in the business of a secondhand dealer without
first having obtained a license therefor from the Municipal Clerk. A separate
license shall be required for each separate location at which a business is
conducted. No person, for himself or herself or as the agent of any dealer in
secondhand articles described in Section
828.01, shall solicit the purchase or sale of any of the aforesaid articles or
property within the City without first having obtained a license therefor from
the Municipal Clerk.
   (b)    Application for such a license shall be in writing to the Municipal
Clerk upon such form as may be prescribed therefor by the Municipal Clerk and
shall contain the name of the person applying for such license; if a firm, the
names of all persons interested therein; the address or addresses at which such
business will be conducted; and such other and further information as may be
required by the Municipal Clerk. (Ord. 25-81. Passed 4-14-81.)
828.03  LICENSE FEES.
   For the license required by Section
828.02, the applicant shall pay the following fees: for a secondhand dealer's
license, excepting those secondhand dealers dealing solely in the sale of
articles or items of property taken as trade-ins on new merchandise, seventy-
five dollars ($75.00); for secondhand dealers dealing solely in the sale of
secondhand articles or items of property taken as trade-ins on new merchandise
sold by such persons, seventeen dollars ($17.00). The aforesaid amounts shall
be the annual license fees or the renewal fees therefor.
(Ord. 25-81. Passed 4-14-81.)
828.04  RECORD OF ACQUISITIONS.
   (a)    Every person required to be licensed under this chapter shall keep a
book in which shall be written in ink in the English language, at the time of
purchase of any secondhand article, a description thereof and the price paid
the seller therefor, together with a statement of the age and address of the
person from whom such purchase was made, a personal description of such person
and the date and hour of such purchase, which statement shall also be signed in
the book by the seller. Such book shall at all times be open to the inspection
of any member of the Police Division. Such book shall be substantially bound
and of a size not less than six inches in length and breadth. In addition to
such book, every person required to be so licensed shall at the time of such
purchase fill out on such blank as may be directed by the Police Division, such
information as may be called for by such blank form, and on the back of such
blank form such seller shall write, in his or her own handwriting, his or her
name, age and address. No entry in such book or on such card shall be erased,
obliterated, altered or defaced.
   (b)    Prior to purchasing any secondhand article for the purpose of resale
to the general public, the buyer shall demand to examine the seller's driver's
license or identification card issued under Ohio R.C. 4507.50 to 4507.52 and
one additional type of card typically used for identification purposes.
   (c)    The purchaser shall keep a written record of the number of the
license or identification card and the type and number of the other
identification card accepted, together with the date of purchase, the name and
address of the seller and a description of the article purchased. The purchaser
shall retain the written record for at least one year and shall make the record
available for inspection by any law enforcement officer at all reasonable
times. For the purposes of this subsection, the purchaser may utilize the
written record he or she is required to keep, where applicable under subsection
(a) hereof, and add to it the information required by this subsection.
(Ord. 25-81. Passed 4-14-81.)
828.05  RECORD OF SALES.
   At the time of the sale or disposition of any secondhand article, the
secondhand dealer disposing thereof shall enter in his or her record book,
along with the entry made at the time of acquisition of the secondhand article,
the name, address and description of the person to whom such secondhand article
is transferred and shall obtain in ink in his or her record book the signature
of the person acquiring such secondhand article. (Ord. 25-81. Passed 4-14-81.)
828.06  FOURTEEN-DAY RETENTION REQUIRED.
   All secondhand articles purchased or received by any person required to be
licensed under this chapter shall be held by such dealer for a period of
fourteen days after being purchased or acquired, unless the disposition of such
articles is sooner authorized by the written permission of the Division of
Police.
(Ord. 36-88. Passed 4-19-88.)
828.07  WEEKLY REPORT TO DIVISION OF POLICE.
   A person required to be licensed under this chapter shall, before 12:00 noon
of the first business day of each week, report to the Division of Police, on
forms to be furnished by such Division, a description of all secondhand
articles received by him or her by purchase during the week immediately
preceding, together with the amounts paid therefor.
(Ord. 25-81. Passed 4-14-81.)
828.08  PURCHASE FROM MINORS PROHIBITED.
   No person required to be licensed under this chapter shall purchase any
article from a minor, or from a person who appears at that time to be under the
influence of alcohol or drugs, or from any person between the hours of 9:00
p.m. and 7:00 a.m.
(Ord. 25-81. Passed 4-14-81.)
828.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00). For a second offense, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor
of the fourth degree and shall be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both. For a third or
subsequent offense, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree
and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned
not more than sixty days, or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 25-81.
Passed 4-14-81.)
CHAPTER 836
Garage Sales
836.01   Garage sale defined.
836.02   General restrictions; signs.
836.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Dealers in secondhand articles - see B.R. &T. Ch.
828
Peddlers, solicitors and canvassers - see B.R. &T. Ch.
852
Licensing in general - see B.R.&T. Ch.
804
 
836.01  GARAGE SALE DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "garage sale" means any temporary private sale of
personal property and merchandise which must be intended solely for domestic or
household use, on a resident's property, which sale is open to the public.
"Garage sale" includes, but is not limited to, yard sales, moving sales,
driveway sales, porch sales and the like.
(Ord. 44-88. Passed 5-3-88.)
836.02  GENERAL RESTRICTIONS; SIGNS.
   Garage sales are subject to the following regulations:
   (a)    No resident or single address shall conduct more than four such sales
per calendar year.
   (b)    No such sale shall continue for a period of more than three
consecutive calendar days.
   (c)    Temporary signs advertising or announcing a garage sale shall:    
      (1)    Not be placed in the public right of way;
      (2)    Be exhibited during the hours of sale only, and twenty-four hours
in advance and twenty-four hours after; and
      (3)    Be exempt from sign permit requirements.
   (d)    All merchandise offered for public sale must be intended solely for
domestic or household use and displayed on private property only.
   (e)    The provisions of the Traffic Code shall be followed.
      (Ord. 44-88. Passed 5-3-88.)
836.99  PENALTY. 
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 44-88. Passed 5-3-88.)
CHAPTER 852
Peddlers and Solicitors
852.01    Definitions.
852.02    Registration required.
852.03    Furnishing of information.
852.04    Restrictions.
852.05    Trespassing in violation of posted signs.
852.99    Penalty.
852.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Peddling” or “soliciting” unless expressly provided for otherwise,
means traveling from residence to residence within the City, without having a
previous appointment to visit the residence or residences visited for the
purpose of exposing or offering for inspection or sale, goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs or any other property, tangible or intangible, of any
nature whatsoever, or services, or for the purpose of taking or attempting to
take orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, or other
property, tangible or intangible, of any nature whatsoever for future delivery,
or of services to be furnished or performed in the future.  “Peddling” or
“soliciting” does not mean the soliciting of funds or other property for
charitable purposes at any residence within the City.  The solicitation by a
newspaper carrier of customers for a newspaper which he/she regularly delivers
or will regularly deliver shall not be included in this definition, nor shall
solicitation for political purposes be included in this definition.
   (b)   “Peddler” or “solicitor”  means any person who engages in peddling or
soliciting.
(Ord. 197-2006.  Passed 12-19-06.)
852.02  REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person shall peddle or solicit within the City without first registering
with the Division of Police.  A separate registration must be made for every
peddler, solicitor, agent or employee soliciting within the City.
(Ord. 197-2006.  Passed 12-19-06.)
852.03  FURNISHING OF INFORMATION.
   (a)   Each peddler or solicitor shall, prior to the time of commencement of
solicitation furnish the Division of Police with the following information on
forms provided by the City:
      (1)   Name and date of birth of applicant.
      (2)   Complete permanent and local address of applicant.
      (3)   Name and address of the person, firm, corporation or association
for whom the solicitation is being made.
      (4)   A description of the nature of the business and the goods, services
or wares to be sold or otherwise sufficient to identify the subject matter of
the soliciting in which the applicant will engage.
      (5)   The proposed dates and times of the solicitation and the routes to
be followed in conducting same.
      (6)   The make, model, year, color and license plate number of
automobiles used by the applicant during the period of solicitation within the
City and the number of the applicant’s driver’s license and state of issuance.
      (7)   Such information shall only be valid for six months from the date
of its furnishing to the Division of Police.
         (Ord. 197-2006.  Passed 12-19-06.)
852.04  RESTRICTIONS.
   Every person to whom this chapter applies shall be governed by the following
rules and regulations:
   (a)   All circulars, samples or other matter shall be handed to an occupant
of the property or left in a secure place on the premises.
   (b)   No person subject to the provisions of this chapter shall peddle or
solicit, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. Eastern Standard
Time or Eastern Daylight Time.
   (c)   No peddler or solicitor shall enter or attempt to enter the house,
apartment, or other dwelling unit of any resident in the City without an
express invitation from the occupant of the house or apartment.
   (d)   No person subject to the terms of this chapter shall make any false,
fraudulent, misleading or deceptive statement during the course of that
person’s soliciting activity within the City.
   (e)   No person subject to this chapter shall make any solicitation where
peddlers or solicitors are notified by a sign that soliciting is prohibited as
provided in Section
852.05.
   (f)   No peddler or solicitor shall engage in or transact any type of
business or solicitation other than that specified on the registration
certificate.
      (Ord. 197-2006.  Passed 12-19-06.)
852.05  TRESPASSING IN VIOLATION OF POSTED SIGNS.
   No person while engaged in any for profit solicitation, shall knock at the
door or ring the bell of any home, apartment, apartment building or other
dwelling unit in the City upon which is displayed at the entrance a notice that
reads “No Peddlers or Solicitors Allowed”, or which otherwise clearly purports
to prohibit peddlers or solicitors on the premises, unless such peddler or
solicitor is, or has been invited upon the premises by the owners, lessee or
occupant thereof.
(Ord. 197-2006.  Passed 12-19-06.)
852.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.  Penalty shall be as provided in Section
698.02.
(Ord. 197-2006.  Passed 12-19-06.)
CHAPTER 856
Private Investigators
856.01   License required.
856.02   Definitions.
856.03   Exceptions.
856.04   License application.
856.05   Bond and insurance required.
856.06   License issuance.
856.07   License duration; fees.
856.08   License revocation.
856.09   Reports to be filed with Police Chief.
856.10   Badges.
856.11   Radios.
856.12   Oath.
856.13   Right of appeal.
856.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
"Oath" defined - see ADM.
202.02(h)
Failure to report a crime - see GEN. OFF.
606.12
Obstructing justice - see GEN. OFF.
606.15
Personating an officer - see GEN. OFF.
606.25,
642.20
 
856.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a private investigation agency or act as a private
investigator within the City unless duly licensed as provided by this chapter.
   No person shall knowingly employ or hire the services of an unlicensed
private investigator or private investigation agency.
(Ord. 24-54. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.02  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Private investigation" means the conducting or making, for hire, of
any investigation for the purpose of:
      (1)    Obtaining evidence or testimony to be used before investigating
committees, boards of award or arbitration, or in the trial of civil or
criminal cases; or
      (2)    Obtaining information with reference to any of the following
matters:
         A.    Crimes and offenses, or wrongs done or threatened;
         B.    The habits, conduct, movements, associates, transactions,
reputation, character or location of persons, firms or corporations;
         C.    The credibility of witnesses or other persons;
         D.    The location or recovery of lost or stolen property; or
         E.    The causes, origin or responsibility for fires or accidents, or
injuries to real or personal property, or strikes and labor difficulties.
   (b)    "Private investigator" means any person who engages in private
investigation for hire, whether self-employed or employed by a private
investigation agency.
   (c)    "Private investigation agency" means a person, firm or corporation
employing in the private investigation business one or more private
investigators.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.03  EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following:
   (a)    Employment as regularly appointed police officers, regularly
appointed peace officers or law enforcement agents of the United States, the
State or political subdivisions thereof;
   (b)    Off-duty employment of regularly appointed police officers of the
City when approved by the Police Chief or of regularly appointed members of the
Wood County Sheriff's Office when approved by the Sheriff;
   (c)    The protection of persons or property being transported in interstate
or intrastate commerce;
   (d)    Persons employed in private business establishments, premises or
structures other than places of amusement, recreation and entertainment where
the major portion of such employment is confined to services within such
private establishments, premises or structures;
   (e)    The investigation and adjustment of insurance losses;
   (f)    Attorneys at law in the practice of their profession;
   (g)    Agencies whose exclusive business is the furnishing of information as
to the business and financial standing and credit responsibility of persons,
firms and corporations, or personal habits and financial responsibility of
applicants or claimants with respect to insurance, indemnity bonds or
commercial credit; or
   (h)    Any person particularly skilled as a workman or in the knowledge of a
particular business, whose employment by any one agency shall not exceed sixty
days in one calendar year. The identity of such persons shall be furnished to
the Police Chief. (Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.04  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for private investigation agency or private investigator
licenses shall be made to the Director of Public Service-Safety on forms
approved by him. Applicants shall be fingerprinted and photographed at the
Police Division.
   Licenses shall be issued only to American citizens of full age who have
resided in the State for not less than one year immediately preceding such
application. Licenses shall not be issued to persons who have been adjudged
insane, convicted of a felony or of a crime or offense involving violence or
moral turpitude, or found upon investigation by the Police Chief not to be of
good character.
   Any person found upon such investigation not to be of good character shall
be entitled, upon request, to a copy of such adverse finding, and shall have
the right of appeal.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.05  BOND AND INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   Each applicant shall file with the Municipal Clerk an approved fidelity bond
in the principal sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) in favor of the City for
the benefit of any person damaged by the dishonest or fraudulent act of the
applicant. Such bond shall be maintained in full force and in the full
principal amount at all times, and shall provide that it shall not be cancelled
or revoked until ten days after written notice of intention so to cancel or
revoke has been given to the Clerk.
   In addition to the bond, each applicant shall file with the Clerk an
approved policy of public liability insurance including coverage for false
arrest, having coverage limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) per
person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) per accident and fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000) property damage. Such policy of insurance shall be
maintained in full force and full coverage at all times, and shall provide that
it shall not be cancelled or revoked until ten days after written notice of
intention so to cancel or revoke has been given to the Clerk.
   The insolvency or bankruptcy of the licensee shall not operate to release
the surety or insurer from liability upon the bond or policy of insurance.
856.06  LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   The Director of Public Service-Safety, upon being satisfied that there is a
necessity therefor, and that the applicant is of good moral character,
competency and integrity, and has complied with all the requirements of this
chapter, including payment of the proper license fee, shall issue licenses for
private investigators and private investigation agencies.
   In the event that the Director declines to issue such license, the person
adversely affected shall have the right of appeal. (Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-
64.)
856.07  LICENSE EXPIRATION; FEES.
   All licenses granted under this chapter shall expire December 31 of each
year, unless sooner revoked. The following fees shall be charged:
   For a private investigator, ten dollars ($10.00);
   For a private investigation agency, twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
   The license for a private investigator shall be in such form as to contain a
true photograph and right thumb print of the licensee, his name, address,
physical description and signature, and shall be carried by the licensee during
his hours of employment or duty. It shall be subject at all times to inspection
by any member of the Police Division.
   The license for a private investigation agency shall be in a form prescribed
by the Director of Public Service-Safety and shall be displayed at the
licensee's office.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.08  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   The Director of Public Service-Safety is hereby authorized to suspend or
revoke any license granted under this chapter, and to refuse to grant or renew
any license to any person because of a violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter.
   Any person adversely affected by any act of the Director under this section
shall have  the right of appeal.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.09  REPORTS TO BE FILED WITH POLICE CHIEF.
   Every private investigation agency licensee shall immediately submit to the
Police Chief in writing the names of all persons in its employ, and thereafter
the names of all persons hired and/or discharged.
   Licensees shall report all police action taken, except routine patrol duty,
to the Police Chief within twelve hours, and shall report as soon as
practicable to the Police Chief all property found or recovered.
   Licensees shall report all knowledge or information of any crime to the
Police Division. (Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.10  BADGES.
   Licensed private investigators may carry badges approved by the Police
Chief. The design of such badge shall differ from that worn by members of the
Police Division.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.11  RADIOS.
   Vehicles equipped with radios capable of being tuned to the Perrysburg
police frequency shall not be used without the knowledge of the Police Chief.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.12  OATH.
   Upon issuance of a license, the licensee shall take and subscribe to an oath
or affirmation similar to that administered to police officers of the City.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.13  RIGHT OF APPEAL.
   Any decision of the Police Chief or Director of Public Service-Safety made
pursuant to this chapter may be appealed to Council. The appeal shall be filed
within ten days of the date of such decision by any person adversely affected
thereby. An appeal shall be perfected by the appellant filing with the Director
a written notice of his intention to appeal, together with a deposit of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00), which sum shall be refunded to the appellant in case
Council renders a decision in favor of the appellant; otherwise, the deposit
shall be forfeited to the City. The decision of Council shall be rendered
within fifteen days from hearing and shall be final.
(Ord. 24-64. Passed 10-27-64.)
856.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
804.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 870
Self-Service Filling Stations
870.01   Definitions.
870.02   General standards; conflict of laws.
870.03   Duties of operators and attendants.
870.04   Signs.
870.05   Dispensing devices and other equipment.
870.06   Operation by customer.
870.07   Option for franchised dealers.
870.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Abandoned gas stations - see P. & Z. Ch.
1215 and Ch.
1280
Ohio Fire Code - see F.P. Ch.
1602
 
870.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)    "Flammable liquid" means a liquid having a flash point below 100
degrees Fahrenheit (37.8 degrees Centigrade) and having a vapor pressure not
exceeding forty pounds per square inch (absolute) at 100 degrees Fahrenheit
(37.8 degrees Centigrade) and shall be known as a Class I liquid.
   (b)    "Self-service filling station" means that portion of property where
flammable and combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and
subsequently dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel
tanks of motor vehicles by persons other than the service station attendant,
and may include facilities available for sale of other retail products.
      (Ord. 34-77. Passed 7-12-77.)
870.02  GENERAL STANDARDS; CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   (a)    Each filling station offering self-service shall be operated in
accordance with National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 30 (1974),
the "Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, " 84 Stat. 1590, 5  U.S.C.A.
5108, regulations adopted by the State Fire Marshal pursuant to Ohio R.C.
3741.14, the Ohio Fire Code, and any amendments thereto and standards adopted
thereunder, and this chapter.
   (b)    In the event of a conflict between any of the standards referred to
in subsection (a) hereof, that requirement which establishes the higher or
stricter standard shall prevail.
(Ord. 34-77. Passed 7-12-77.)
870.03  DUTIES OF OPERATORS AND ATTENDANTS.
   (a)    Each filling station offering self-service shall be under the direct
control of a supervisor, employee or attendant at all times when gasoline or
other flammable liquids are being dispensed or sold.
   (b)    The operator of the filling station shall see that all attendant
employees are properly trained in handling emergencies of the flammable fuel
type.
   (c)    The operator of the filling station shall see that all attendant
employees read and are familiar with applicable codes and standards.
   (d)    The attendant's primary function shall be to supervise, observe and
control the dispensing of Class I liquids while such liquids are actually being
dispensed.
   (e)    The attendant shall not authorize the dispensing of a Class I liquid
from the self- service dispensers until he or she has ascertained that a Class
I liquid can be safely dispensed.
   (f)   The attendant shall:
      (1)    Not dispense a Class I liquid into a portable container unless the
container is constructed of metal or is approved by the Fire Prevention
Officer, has a tight closure and is fitted with a spout or so designed that the
contents can be poured without spilling;
      (2)    Control sources of ignition; and
      (3)    Immediately handle accidental spills and fire extinguishers if
needed.
   (g)    The attendant or supervisor on duty shall be mentally and physically
capable of performing the functions and assuming the responsibilities
prescribed in this section.
   (h)    The dispensing area shall, at all times, be in clear view of the
attendant, and the placing or allowing of any obstacle to come between the
dispensing area and the attendant control area is prohibited. The attendant
shall at all times be able to communicate with persons in the dispensing area.
(Ord. 34-77. Passed 7-12-77.)
870.04  SIGNS.
   (a)    A sign, in block letters at least four inches in height, shall be
conspicuously displayed on each gasoline pump island where self-service is
offered, to state that it is a self- service island.
   (b)    Signs giving instructions for the operation of gasoline dispensing
equipment, in block letters at least one-half inch in height, shall be
conspicuously posted at each self-service filling station offering self-
service.
   (c)    A sign bearing the following words, in block letters at least two
inches in height, shall be conspicuously posted on each gasoline pump island
where self-service is offered:
      "STOP ENGINE"
      "NO SMOKING"
"WARNING - IT IS UNLAWFUL AND DANGEROUS TO DISPENSE GASOLINE INTO UNAPPROVED
CONTAINERS."
   (d)    All signs required by this section shall be constructed of rigid,
weather-resistant material. (Ord. 34-77. Passed 7-12-77.)
870.05  DISPENSING DEVICES AND OTHER EQUIPMENT.
   (a)    Gasoline dispensing nozzles used by a person other than a supervisor,
an employee or an attendant shall be of an approved automatic closing-type
without a hold-open latch.
   (b)    Emergency power cut-off controls to shut off the power to all
dispensing devices in the event of an emergency shall be installed at a
location acceptable to the Fire Chief, but the controls shall be not more than
100 feet from the dispensers.
   (c)    Equipment to convert to self-service or new equipment installed for
the purpose of providing self-service shall be approved by a testing laboratory
listed below:
      (1)    The American Gas Association (AGA)
      (2)    The Engineering Experiment Station of the Ohio State University
      (3)    Factory Mutual Research Corporation (FM)
      (4)    The National Bureau of Standards (NBS), Building Research
Division, U. S. Department of Commerce
      (5)    The Ohio Board of Building Standards (BBS)
      (6)    The Southwest Research Institute
      (7)    Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. (UL)
      (8)    The University of California, Department of Civil Engineering
      (9)    Environ Testing Laboratories, Inc.
   (d)    Approved dispensing devices such as, but not limited to, coin-
operated, card- operated and remote controlled types, are permitted at self-
service stations.
(Ord. 34-77. Passed 7-12-77.)
870.06  OPERATION BY CUSTOMER.
   (a)    Gasoline and other flammable liquids shall be dispensed only by a
person who is not smoking and who, in the judgment of the supervisor, employee
or attendant, appears to be able and competent.
   (b)    Dispensing devices shall not be operated by a customer until
activated by the attendant. The attendant shall authorize each individual sale
and shall activate the dispensing device only after such authorization.
(Ord. 34-77. Passed 7-12-77.)
870.07  OPTION FOR FRANCHISED DEALERS.
   Franchised dealers shall be allowed the option as to whether they wish to
offer full service, self-service on one island or complete self-service in the
conduct of their business.
(Ord. 34-77. Passed 7-12-77.)
870.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both.
CHAPTER 872
Taxicabs (Repealed)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Chapter

CHAPTER 874
Video Service Provider Fee
874.01    Fee established.
874.02    Notice.
874.03    Effective date.
874.01  FEE ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   The City of Perrysburg hereby adopts, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 1332.32, a
video service provider fee, such fee shall uniformly apply to all video service
providers within the City.
   (b)   The fee shall consist of five percent (5%) of the video service
provider’s gross revenues as defined by Ohio R.C. 1332.32(B)(1)(a) through (e)
and on advertising revenue as set forth in Ohio R.C. 1332.32(B)(2)(g).
(Ord. 131-2007.  Passed 8-21-07.)
874.02  NOTICE.
   (a)   Either the Mayor or the Administrator is hereby authorized and
directed to provide the written notice required by Ohio R.C. 1332.32(C)(2) upon
receipt of notice by a video service provider that it will commence to provide
access to video service in the City.
   (b)   Either the Mayor or the Administrator is hereby authorized and
directed to promptly notify affected video service providers of this chapter.
(Ord. 131-2007.  Passed 8-21-07.)
874.03  EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This chapter shall not take effect until the first day of the first calender
quarter that begins more than thirty days after the notice referred to in
Section
874.02(b).
(Ord. 131-2007.  Passed 8-21-07.)

CHAPTER 890
Municipal Income Tax for Taxable Years 2015 and Prior
 
EDITOR’S NOTE: See Chapter
891 for income tax effective January 1, 2016.
890.01   Purpose of tax.
890.02   Definitions.
890.03   Imposition of tax.
890.04   Effective period.
890.05   Annual tax returns and payment of tax.
890.06   Collection at source.
890.07   Declarations; estimated  tax payments.
890.08   Duties of Commissioner.
890.09   Investigative powers of  Commissioner; divulging confidential
information.
890.10   Interest and penalties.
890.11   Collection of unpaid taxes by litigation;  refunds of  overpayments.
890.12   Board of Review.
890.13   Allocation of funds.
890.14   Credit for tax paid to other municipalities.
890.15   Separability.
890.16   Collection of tax after termination of chapter.
890.17   Violations; limitation on prosecutions.
890.99   Penalty.
